ground_truth:
I have to call Georgia for help with the air conditioner. “I thought I couldn’t come over this weekend,” she says.

“I don’t think I can lift it by myself.”

“I see.” I can hear her washing dishes. “So I’m allowed to come over if you need something.”

She arrives within five minutes, as I knew she would. Under the brim of her straw hat her eyes are like peas in aspic. She has a dishcloth tucked into a pocket of her jeans. Georgia has never been married, but she is a better version of the wife I used to be. Her grocery lists say six damask plums where I would write fruit.

“Don’t worry,” she says, taking the screen out of the window. “I’ll be gone by the time they get here.”

“Thank you.” I kiss her hand.

“If you want to thank me, invite me to dinner tonight.”

“Maybe,” I say, but we both know I won’t.


Colt arrives in tight jeans and a bolo tie, his father’s old typewriter in his arms. He sets it on the kitchen table.

“You guys can take my room. And yes, I put in the air conditioner.”

“Don’t know how you live without it.” He takes his shoes off before he goes upstairs. That was one of his father’s rules.

I hold the front door open for my daughter-in-law and her suitcase. Her red hair is in a pompadour, left over from last night’s party. When she kisses my cheek I smell coconut pomade.

“I asked him not to bring that,” Vivian says, looking at the typewriter. “He could use a few days off from work.”

“Would you like some juice? I have orange and pineapple.”

“No, thanks. Too much sugar.” Vivian, all hip bones and rib cage, is afraid of sugar.

I wait until she is upstairs before addressing the typewriter.

“Get out,” I tell the well-worn keys. “Get out.”


Nothing that belongs to Oliver is allowed in my house. When he left me I held a tag sale on my front lawn. The first days passed without a single prospect. People were shy. They knew Oliver as the man who spread fireplace ashes on icy steps. They remembered when he cleared the road of tree branches after a hurricane. But I knew I could trust a free market. Was I really selling that guitar for five dollars? I was.

I met Georgia at my sale, over a canvas bag of my wedding china. She’d moved to the neighborhood a year before, and I knew as much about her as did everyone else on our street: she was a spinster who’d made an enormous web of pulled cotton to cover her front windows at Halloween, and at Christmas she left icebox cookies in our mailboxes. She was wearing a souvenir T-shirt from Hollywood, and between her breasts a giant palm tree waved its sequined fronds.

“How much for the china?” she’d said.

“I don’t want anything for that.”

“How much?”

“Zero dollars and zero cents.”

She picked up a tempered-glass paperweight shaped like an abalone shell. “I’ll give you five dollars for this, and no less than fifty for the china.”

I was drinking a beer, which I set aside to count her change. “This isn’t how bargaining usually works,” I said.

“I don’t want to feel like I’m stealing something,” she said.


Colt comes downstairs with a copy of his novel in his hands.

“Found this by the tub. How far are you?”

“I started it.” I unwrap a rack of spareribs and set them on a baking sheet. I regret, for a moment, that I sold Oliver’s grill for a dime.

“You’re offended by the title. I knew you’d be offended.”

He sits at the table and props one foot on a chair. This makes me miss his childhood. I kiss the top of his head.

“No,” I say, “though I guess slut isn’t one of my favorite words.”

It doesn’t bother me that Colt’s book is called The Confessions of Slut Twenty-Three; nor does it bother me that Slut Twenty-Three, in the pages I’ve skimmed, physically resembles Vivian. If what he writes is taken from their lives, Vivian randomly demands sex in parking lots, makes Colt wear her hosiery, and runs a blow-job clinic in the smoking garden of a local bar.

I am not offended by his pedantic diagrams of sexual positions, or by the character named Mlle Fuck-You. It’s the shrill, smug voice he picked up in college that I can’t stand. His narrator, The-Man-in-Love-with-the-Slut, describes himself as “your average spoiled white kid from the suburbs.”

“You are not a ‘white kid from the suburbs,’ ” I want to tell him. “You’re from a small town nowhere near a city. You were raised to treat people decently. And your father and I never spoiled you.” But I know—I know, I know—that this is not an autobiography.

I believe Colt when he tells me that in certain circles he is famous. Once I suggested that those circles might be concentrated in Brooklyn, and my throat closed with guilt the moment I said it. Colt is my delight; he is my only child. For nine months I prayed for the healthy heart now beating under his shirt. As soon as I could hold him, heart and all, I sensed the futility of prayer. I knew that every time he was hurt it would be my fault.


They smoked a joint right before dinner while I picked green beans from the garden. Colt’s elbows are on the table. He tells us, several times, that he would love it if some backwoods library in the Deep South banned his book.

“Enough about you,” Vivian says.

“Okay. Tell Mom about your new business idea,” he says.

“We have this dog park near our building, and the people are ridiculous. They dress the dogs in little quilted jackets. They give them the same kinds of names they give their kids: Jordan, Mason, Hunter, Taylor.”

“So ridiculous,” Colt says.

“Anyway, there’s a multilingual school down the street from the park. I thought maybe people would be into a multilingual class for dogs. Not like they think the dog is going to speak, but so a dog can follow commands in three or four languages.”

“You’re kidding, right?”

“I am, but I’m not. I think if we charged $75 per session, we might convince some people it’s worth paying for. So that might be my project for the next six months.” The look they exchange tells me this joke has been broken in, and that every time she tells it, Colt is charmed.

“What about you, Mom?” he says. “What do you see yourself doing in the next six months?”

“Maybe some camping up in Acadia before it gets too cold.” Georgia and I have been planning this trip for months.

“But who would go with you?”

“Yeah, who would go with you?”

They give me a pitying look. They think I am alone, and they think they are invincible. Vivian has no visible reaction to Colt’s hand on the back of her neck. This is the smugness of having your lover beside you all the time. I want to tell her that being loved this much leaves no mark. If Colt rises from the table, she will look as lonely as I do.


Sometimes I wish Colt would find the whole thing abhorrent. Two women? Disgusting. His own mother? Disgusting. If he could back away from it, maybe I could tell him. But Colt and Viv would levitate with pleasure. They’d sit there thinking they’d finally figured me out: there’s Mom, Judith, clear as an egg wash, a classic closet case. Maybe she’s been waiting for Georgia her whole life.

Surely Colt remembers the traffic jam. A westbound lane on the Sagamore Bridge, a cup of rum-raisin ice cream in his hand, his head out the window to watch the Cape Cod Canal churning with rain, traces of zinc oxide on his nose. He was eleven. He asked his parents, “Have either of you ever been in love?”

Oliver had just given me opal earrings for my birthday, suffered a lobster dinner on my behalf.

“Of course, son,” he said, reaching back to tousle his hair.

I couldn’t stop wondering why Colt would ask us that.

“He asks why we can’t take vacation on a different planet. He asks why we can’t drink saltwater. I wouldn’t worry about this,” Oliver said.

We were in the yard, the grass freshly mowed, mosquitoes biting freely as dusk unraveled. It was a Saturday, the night Oliver was allowed to get drunk. Colt was at a friend’s house, observing marriages that were apparently stronger than mine.

“Give me a priss, kitty,” Oliver said. “Stop worrying.”

I worried even more after that.


I can see it now: Georgia in a souvenir T-shirt, a shade overweight, telling stories as if we’ve been married for years. The three of them teasing me for voting Republican. “I always knew there was a liberal in there somewhere,” Colt will say. They will need a little less from me, a little more from each other; I in turn will need a little more from all of them.

They’ll have cocktail hour while I drink club soda with lime. Georgia will mix vodka and grenadine, even though I’ve told her it’s tacky. She doesn’t mind being teased, and she doesn’t know how to be jealous, two of my favorite things about her. She indulges me when I need to talk about my married life. She knows how many buttons I had on my wedding dress. She knows that Oliver and I spent our wedding night at the Pioneer Hotel, with its misplaced neoclassical columns. The windows were jalousies, and there was only one towel in the bathroom. There was a folding screen, and I’d felt obliged to change behind it, even though we’d seen each other naked many times.


I call Vivian to the bathroom after my shower. She is pleased. This is the kind of thing daughters-in-law do: they enter intimate spaces unflinchingly.

“Take a look at this mole,” I tell her, pulling my robe away from my breast. “I swear I didn’t have it this morning.”

She excuses herself to get her glasses from her handbag.

“That’s not a mole, Judith. That’s a tick.”

“It looks like a mole.”

“That’s because he’s in there pretty deep.”

“Well, shit,” I say. “Can you get it out?”

First she tries tweezers, which I keep on a mirrored tray by the sink.

“This fucker’s really in there,” she says.

My eyes are watery, my head hot.

“Do you think I might already have Lyme disease?”

“Don’t be ridiculous,” she says, the first hint of a mother I’ve ever seen in her.

When Vivian worries the tweezers are making it worse, she asks Colt to bring matches. There are holes in the knees of her jeans, and her fingernails are painted gold. She has a scar on her arm from breaking a window when her father refused to give her his credit card. (She was, she has assured me, only twenty-two at the time.) This is the girl who holds a flame close to my skin.

When she finally gets the tick out without starting a fire, I offer her fifty dollars. “An investment in your multilingual dog business.”

“Just watch for a bull’s-eye around the bite. If you see a bull’s-eye, we’ll need to go to the doctor in the morning,” she says.


I lie awake with all the lights on, watching for a bull’s-eye.

When Georgia can’t sleep, I comb her hair. When I can’t sleep, she tells me about her childhood. She has three older brothers. In their yard they had a set of dolphin-shaped swings that appeared to be caught by their chains. The Connecticut River sluiced the edge of their property. The swings were still there when Georgia drove me past the house this summer, but the place was dingy and run-down. One of the panes in the front door was sealed with a piece of cardboard, and someone had spray-painted the word keep on the side of the house.

“Oh, well,” Georgia said. “Maybe some college students live there now.”

I could be that calm too, if I’d never had to iron an impatient man’s shirt or peel a soft-boiled egg for a screaming child. I am not the kind of woman who complains about the life she was meant to have: I was supposed to be handling shirts and eggs. My husband was supposed to be faithful.

In the years I was tending to Colt and Oliver, Georgia was serving her family as the quirky unmarried one. She drove her nieces and nephews to zoos. She bought them geodes and suspended prisms in their windows. If she ever meets my son, she will become his cheerful aunt. She’s already read his novel twice.

“You need to introduce me to Colt soon,” she said recently. I was driving her home from the doctor’s office. “It’s kind of insulting.”

“Could you turn the AC down? It’s freezing in here.”

“You think I’m too nice to give you a hard time about this, don’t you.”

“No,” I said, but I laughed.

“I’m serious, Judith. I’m not afraid to piss you off.”

“Don’t I know it,” I said, but I am almost never mad at Georgia. It was Oliver who drew anger out of me. Oliver, capricious and unapologetic, a man who kept me guessing every day of our marriage.

When we were first dating, I couldn’t decide how to greet him. He never learned how to embrace. He let you press your body into his chest, but his arms were limp and useless. His firm handshake was so brief you couldn’t tell if his skin was warm. That was me: choosing between one of his hands and two of his arms, weighing the trade-off, wanting more than I could get.
story_a:
Judith had always found solace in routine. The morning light would filter through the lace curtains, casting delicate shadows on the kitchen floor as she brewed her coffee. The scent of freshly ground beans filled the air, mingling with the faint aroma of lavender from the garden. It was a small comfort, a daily ritual that anchored her amidst the chaos of a life recently upended by divorce.

Today, as she stood by the window, cradling her mug, Judith watched the world outside with a sense of detachment. The oak tree in her front yard, its branches swaying gently in the autumn breeze, seemed to mock her with its steadfastness. She sipped her coffee, letting the warmth seep into her bones, and wondered how everything had changed so quickly.

Her son, Ethan, had always been a quiet, introspective boy. Even now, as a grown man, there was an air of mystery about him that Judith could never quite penetrate. He had married young, to a woman named Lara, whose boldness and vivacity were a stark contrast to Ethan's reserved nature. Judith had never fully understood their dynamic, but she had accepted it, hoping that Lara's energy would draw Ethan out of his shell.

It was only after the divorce that Judith realized how little she truly knew her son. He had moved back in with her temporarily, bringing Lara with him. The house, once a sanctuary of calm, now buzzed with tension and unspoken words.

Judith had never been one for confrontation, preferring to let things lie rather than stir the pot. But living with Ethan and Lara had forced her to confront the cracks in their relationship, cracks that mirrored her own failed marriage. She could see the strain in the way Lara's eyes darted away when Ethan spoke, the way Ethan's shoulders tensed whenever Lara entered the room.

And then there was Georgia, the quirky neighbor who had moved in next door a few months ago. With her shock of curly red hair and penchant for eccentric clothing, Georgia was a breath of fresh air in Judith's otherwise staid existence. She had a way of seeing through Judith's carefully constructed facade, of piercing the veil of politeness that Judith wore like armor.

"Morning, Judith!" Georgia called from her porch, waving a brightly colored scarf in greeting. Judith smiled and waved back, feeling a pang of gratitude for the woman's relentless cheerfulness.

Georgia had an uncanny ability to appear just when Judith needed her most. Whether it was a spontaneous invitation for tea or a quick chat over the garden fence, Georgia's presence was a balm to Judith's wounded soul.

"Got any plans for the day?" Georgia asked, her voice carrying across the lawn.

Judith shook her head. "Just the usual, I suppose. Cleaning, cooking, trying to stay out of the way."

Georgia's eyes sparkled with mischief. "Why don't you come over for a bit? I've got a new batch of herbal tea I want you to try. It's supposed to be great for stress."

Judith hesitated, glancing back at the house. She could hear the faint murmur of Ethan and Lara's voices, muffled by the walls but still unmistakably strained. A part of her wanted to retreat, to bury herself in the familiar comfort of her routines. But another part, the part that had been slowly awakening since the divorce, urged her to step outside her comfort zone.

"Alright," she said, surprising herself with the firmness in her voice. "I'll be over in a few minutes."

Georgia beamed. "Great! I'll put the kettle on."

As Judith made her way next door, she couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation. It was a small thing, a simple visit to a neighbor, but it felt like a step toward something new, something different.

Georgia's house was a riot of color and eclectic decor, a stark contrast to Judith's own subdued home. The walls were adorned with vibrant tapestries and framed photographs, while the shelves overflowed with knick-knacks and mementos from Georgia's travels.

"Welcome to my humble abode," Georgia said with a flourish, leading Judith to the cozy kitchen nook. "Sit, sit! I'll get the tea."

Judith settled into a cushioned chair, taking in the whirlwind of sights and sounds around her. It was chaotic, but in a way that felt alive and invigorating.

"How are things at home?" Georgia asked, setting a steaming cup of tea in front of Judith.

Judith sighed, wrapping her hands around the warm mug. "Complicated, as always. Ethan and Lara... I don't know. I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around them."

Georgia nodded sympathetically. "Relationships are tricky, aren't they? Sometimes it feels like no matter what you do, you can't get it right."

Judith took a sip of the tea, savoring the soothing blend of herbs. "I just wish I knew how to help them. How to fix things."

"Maybe it's not about fixing," Georgia said gently. "Maybe it's about understanding. Sometimes, the best thing we can do is just be there, to listen and support without trying to solve everything."

Judith pondered Georgia's words, feeling a flicker of hope. Perhaps she had been going about it all wrong, trying to mend what was broken instead of simply being present.

"You're right," she said softly. "I've been so focused on trying to make things better that I haven't really been there for them."

Georgia smiled, reaching across the table to squeeze Judith's hand. "It's never too late to start."

Judith left Georgia's house with a renewed sense of purpose. She couldn't change the past, but she could be there for Ethan and Lara in the present. She could listen, support, and try to understand.

That evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, Judith found herself in the kitchen, preparing dinner. The rhythmic chopping of vegetables was a soothing balm to her frayed nerves. She could hear Ethan and Lara in the living room, their voices low and strained.

Taking a deep breath, Judith wiped her hands on a dish towel and made her way to the living room. Ethan looked up, surprise flickering in his eyes as she entered.

"Dinner will be ready soon," she said, her voice steady. "But I was hoping we could talk for a bit first."

Lara glanced at Ethan, then back at Judith. "Sure," she said cautiously.

Judith sat down, feeling the weight of the moment. "I know things have been difficult lately," she began, choosing her words carefully. "And I know I haven't been the best at supporting you both. But I want to change that. I want to be here for you, to listen and understand."

Ethan's gaze softened, and for the first time in weeks, Judith saw a glimmer of the boy she had raised, the boy who had once confided in her about his hopes and fears.

"It's not easy," Ethan said quietly. "Marriage, life... it's all so much harder than I thought it would be."

Lara nodded, her eyes filling with unshed tears. "We've been struggling, trying to make things work, but it feels like we're just drifting further apart."

Judith reached out, taking both their hands in hers. "You're not alone in this. We can figure it out together."

They talked long into the night, sharing their fears, frustrations, and hopes. It was a beginning, a tentative step toward healing and understanding.

In the days that followed, Judith made a conscious effort to be more present, to truly listen and support without trying to fix everything. It wasn't always easy, and there were still moments of tension and uncertainty. But there was also a growing sense of connection, a fragile but genuine bond that began to form between them.

One afternoon, as Judith worked in her garden, she felt a presence beside her. Looking up, she saw Georgia, her ever-present smile lighting up her face.

"How's it going?" Georgia asked, her eyes twinkling with curiosity.

Judith wiped the sweat from her brow, feeling a sense of accomplishment. "Better, I think. We're talking more, trying to understand each other. It's a slow process, but it feels like progress."

Georgia nodded approvingly. "That's wonderful to hear. Sometimes, it's the small steps that make the biggest difference."

Judith smiled, feeling a surge of gratitude for the woman who had become her friend and confidante. "Thank you, Georgia. For everything."

Georgia waved off her thanks with a laugh. "Oh, don't mention it. We're all just trying to figure this life thing out together, right?"

As the weeks turned into months, Judith found herself growing more comfortable with the new rhythm of her life. She discovered strength she hadn't known she possessed, a resilience that carried her through the challenges she faced.

Ethan and Lara continued to navigate their own struggles, but there was a newfound openness between them. They began attending couples therapy, working through their issues with a determination that both impressed and humbled Judith.

One evening, as they sat around the dinner table, Lara reached for Judith's hand. "Thank you," she said, her voice filled with sincerity. "For being there for us, for believing in us."

Judith felt a lump form in her throat, her heart swelling with emotion. "I'm so proud of you both," she said, her voice trembling. "You've come so far, and I know you'll continue to grow together."

Ethan squeezed her hand, his eyes shining with gratitude. "We couldn't have done it without you, Mom."

As they shared a meal, laughter and conversation filling the air, Judith felt a sense of peace she hadn't known in a long time. The road ahead was still uncertain, but she knew they would face it together, with love and understanding guiding their way.

Later that night, as she lay in bed, Judith reflected on the journey she had taken since her divorce. It had been a difficult and often painful path, but it had also been a journey of self-discovery and growth. She had found strength in herself and in the connections she had forged with those around her.

And as she drifted off to sleep, the gentle rustle of the oak tree outside her window a comforting lullaby, Judith knew that she was exactly where she was meant to be.
story_b:
Judith stood in the middle of her living room, surrounded by a sea of cardboard boxes, the scent of fresh paint lingering in the air. It was her first night in the new apartment, and the walls echoed with the unfamiliar emptiness of a space not yet lived in. She ran her fingers across the smooth surface of a nearby box labeled "Kitchen," wondering if she had packed her favorite mug with the chipped handle that had seen her through countless cups of late-night tea.

She heard a knock at the door and hesitated for a moment, then opened it to find Georgia, her neighbor from down the hall, standing there with a bottle of wine and a slightly mischievous grin. Georgia was in her mid-fifties, with short, spiky hair and a collection of bangles clinking on her wrist. She always seemed to carry an air of unpredictability, like a summer storm that could break into sunshine at any moment.

"Thought you might need some company," Georgia said, waving the bottle. "And maybe a break from unpacking. I know how daunting it can be."

Judith stepped aside to let her in, feeling both grateful and apprehensive. Georgia's presence was a whirlwind, and Judith wasn't sure if she was ready for that kind of energy just yet. But as the night wore on, she found herself laughing more than she had in months, her worries temporarily swept away by the warmth of Georgia's laughter filling the room.

"So, what's the deal with your son and his wife?" Georgia asked casually, refilling their glasses with a practiced hand.

Judith sighed, the question bringing a familiar weight back to her chest. "Evan's been...distant since the divorce. I think he's trying to find his own way of dealing with it, and Rachel, well, she's always been quite bold. She has this way of pushing boundaries that I'm still getting used to."

"Bold can be good," Georgia mused, swirling her wine. "Sometimes it takes a bold move to see things differently, don't you think?"

Judith nodded slowly, thinking of all the times Rachel's straightforwardness had caught her off guard. Like the time Rachel had insisted on keeping the family tradition of Sunday dinners, despite Judith's reluctance to partake in something that reminded her so much of her married life.

The following Sunday, as Judith sat at the familiar dining table in Evan and Rachel's home, she felt the weight of tradition pressing down on her. The room was filled with the aroma of roast chicken and rosemary, and Judith watched as her son carved the bird with careful precision, a skill he had inherited from his father.

"Mom, why don't you say grace?" Evan suggested, looking up with a hopeful smile.

Judith hesitated, the words sticking in her throat. It was a simple request, yet it felt like a monumental task. This was the first time she had been asked to lead grace since the divorce, and the familiar prayer felt foreign on her tongue.

Rachel reached out and squeezed her hand. "You don't have to if it makes you uncomfortable. We can start a new tradition."

Judith looked at her daughter-in-law, surprised by the unexpected kindness. Rachel's eyes were earnest, and for the first time, Judith saw her not as the bold intruder but as someone who genuinely wanted to be part of the family, someone who understood the need for change.

"No, it's okay," Judith said finally, finding her voice. "I think it's time for something new."

After dinner, as the conversation flowed easily over dessert, Judith felt a sense of belonging that she hadn't anticipated. It wasn't the same as before, but it was something new, something that felt like growth.

Later that evening, back in her own apartment, Judith sat on the balcony, the cool night air brushing against her skin. She thought of Georgia's words about boldness and seeing things differently. Maybe Georgia was right. Maybe it was time to embrace change rather than fear it.

As if summoned by her thoughts, Georgia appeared at the railing separating their balconies, holding two steaming mugs. "Thought you might like some tea," she said, passing one over.

"How did you know?" Judith asked, cradling the mug in her hands and inhaling the soothing aroma.

"Call it neighborly intuition," Georgia replied with a wink. "Besides, you looked like you could use a friend."

Judith smiled, feeling a warmth spread through her that had nothing to do with the tea. "Thank you. For everything."

"Anytime, Judith. Just remember, life isn't about finding yourself. It's about creating yourself. So go on, create something beautiful."

Judith took a sip of her tea, the steam rising in gentle swirls, and for the first time in a long time, she felt a flicker of hope. Maybe this new life, with all its complexities and challenges, could be beautiful after all. Maybe she just needed to be bold enough to see it.

The days turned into weeks, and Judith found herself falling into a new rhythm. She spent her mornings unpacking and arranging her apartment, each room slowly taking on a personality of its own. In the afternoons, she often found herself on her balcony, sharing stories and laughter with Georgia, whose free spirit was proving to be a balm to Judith’s cautious heart.

One particular afternoon, as they sat watching the clouds drift lazily across the sky, Georgia nudged her. "You know, you should come to one of my art classes."

Judith raised an eyebrow. "Art? I'm not sure I have the talent for that."

"It's not about talent," Georgia assured her. "It's about expression. Besides, it's a great way to meet new people and maybe see things from a different perspective."

Judith hesitated, the idea both intriguing and terrifying. But as she looked at Georgia, she felt a spark of something—curiosity, perhaps, or the desire to try something completely out of her comfort zone.

"Okay," Judith agreed, surprising herself. "I'll give it a try."

The art class was held in a sunlit studio, filled with easels and the smell of acrylic paint. Judith felt self-conscious at first, surrounded by strangers who seemed to know exactly what they were doing. But as she picked up a brush and let the colors flow onto the canvas, she began to lose herself in the rhythm of creation.

It was liberating, this act of painting without fear of judgment, allowing herself to explore emotions she had kept locked away for so long. The art became a silent conversation between her past and present, a way of reconciling who she was with who she was becoming.

As the class ended, Georgia walked over, looking at Judith's canvas with a smile. "See? I knew you'd be great at this."

Judith laughed, feeling a lightness she hadn't felt in years. "I don't know about great, but it was...freeing."

"That's the point," Georgia said, clapping her on the back. "Sometimes you just need to let go and see where the journey takes you."

Later, as Judith returned to her apartment, she found a message from Evan on her phone. He wanted her to join them for dinner again, this time with a special announcement.

Curiosity piqued, Judith agreed, wondering what news her son might have. She arrived at their home to find Rachel bustling around the kitchen, a nervous excitement in her movements.

Evan greeted her with a hug, his smile wide and genuine. "Mom, we have some great news. Rachel and I are expecting."

Judith felt her heart swell with joy and surprise. "Oh, Evan, that's wonderful!" she exclaimed, pulling him into another embrace.

As they sat down to dinner, the atmosphere was filled with warmth and anticipation. Judith watched her son and daughter-in-law, their hands entwined, and felt a sense of peace settle over her. This new chapter in their lives, in her life, was unfolding with possibilities she hadn't dared to imagine.

After dinner, as they lingered over coffee, Rachel turned to Judith with a soft smile. "We were hoping you'd be involved, you know, in the baby's life. We want them to know their grandmother."

Judith nodded, emotion welling up in her chest. "I would love that," she said, her voice thick with gratitude.

Driving home that night, Judith reflected on the changes that had come so swiftly. The divorce had been a turning point, a painful but necessary step toward rediscovering herself. And now, with Evan's growing family and her own burgeoning friendships, she felt a renewed sense of purpose.

Back in her apartment, Judith reached for her phone, texting Georgia about the evening's news. Within minutes, Georgia was at her door, a bottle of champagne in hand.

"Let's celebrate," Georgia declared, popping the cork with a flourish. "To new beginnings and the beautiful chaos of life."

Judith laughed, toasting to the unexpected journey she was on. She had learned to embrace the unknown, to find beauty in the unraveling of plans and the forging of new paths.

As the night wore on, Judith and Georgia sat on the balcony, the city lights twinkling below them. Judith felt a sense of belonging, a contentment she hadn’t thought possible after the upheaval of her divorce.

Georgia turned to her, her expression thoughtful. "You know, Judith, it's okay to let go of what was and embrace what is. You're doing better than you think."

Judith smiled, her heart full. She had found a friend in Georgia, a new understanding with her son and daughter-in-law, and a fresh sense of self. She was no longer defined by her past but by the choices she was making in the present.

The future was still uncertain, but Judith felt ready to face it, to create something beautiful out of the chaos. She was learning to redefine her identity, not as a divorced woman, but as a mother, a friend, an artist, and above all, as herself.

And so, with the warmth of Georgia’s friendship and the love of her family, Judith stepped boldly into the next chapter of her life, ready to embrace whatever came her way.

ground_truth:
I have to call Georgia for help with the air conditioner. “I thought I couldn’t come over this weekend,” she says.

“I don’t think I can lift it by myself.”

“I see.” I can hear her washing dishes. “So I’m allowed to come over if you need something.”

She arrives within five minutes, as I knew she would. Under the brim of her straw hat her eyes are like peas in aspic. She has a dishcloth tucked into a pocket of her jeans. Georgia has never been married, but she is a better version of the wife I used to be. Her grocery lists say six damask plums where I would write fruit.

“Don’t worry,” she says, taking the screen out of the window. “I’ll be gone by the time they get here.”

“Thank you.” I kiss her hand.

“If you want to thank me, invite me to dinner tonight.”

“Maybe,” I say, but we both know I won’t.


Colt arrives in tight jeans and a bolo tie, his father’s old typewriter in his arms. He sets it on the kitchen table.

“You guys can take my room. And yes, I put in the air conditioner.”

“Don’t know how you live without it.” He takes his shoes off before he goes upstairs. That was one of his father’s rules.

I hold the front door open for my daughter-in-law and her suitcase. Her red hair is in a pompadour, left over from last night’s party. When she kisses my cheek I smell coconut pomade.

“I asked him not to bring that,” Vivian says, looking at the typewriter. “He could use a few days off from work.”

“Would you like some juice? I have orange and pineapple.”

“No, thanks. Too much sugar.” Vivian, all hip bones and rib cage, is afraid of sugar.

I wait until she is upstairs before addressing the typewriter.

“Get out,” I tell the well-worn keys. “Get out.”


Nothing that belongs to Oliver is allowed in my house. When he left me I held a tag sale on my front lawn. The first days passed without a single prospect. People were shy. They knew Oliver as the man who spread fireplace ashes on icy steps. They remembered when he cleared the road of tree branches after a hurricane. But I knew I could trust a free market. Was I really selling that guitar for five dollars? I was.

I met Georgia at my sale, over a canvas bag of my wedding china. She’d moved to the neighborhood a year before, and I knew as much about her as did everyone else on our street: she was a spinster who’d made an enormous web of pulled cotton to cover her front windows at Halloween, and at Christmas she left icebox cookies in our mailboxes. She was wearing a souvenir T-shirt from Hollywood, and between her breasts a giant palm tree waved its sequined fronds.

“How much for the china?” she’d said.

“I don’t want anything for that.”

“How much?”

“Zero dollars and zero cents.”

She picked up a tempered-glass paperweight shaped like an abalone shell. “I’ll give you five dollars for this, and no less than fifty for the china.”

I was drinking a beer, which I set aside to count her change. “This isn’t how bargaining usually works,” I said.

“I don’t want to feel like I’m stealing something,” she said.


Colt comes downstairs with a copy of his novel in his hands.

“Found this by the tub. How far are you?”

“I started it.” I unwrap a rack of spareribs and set them on a baking sheet. I regret, for a moment, that I sold Oliver’s grill for a dime.

“You’re offended by the title. I knew you’d be offended.”

He sits at the table and props one foot on a chair. This makes me miss his childhood. I kiss the top of his head.

“No,” I say, “though I guess slut isn’t one of my favorite words.”

It doesn’t bother me that Colt’s book is called The Confessions of Slut Twenty-Three; nor does it bother me that Slut Twenty-Three, in the pages I’ve skimmed, physically resembles Vivian. If what he writes is taken from their lives, Vivian randomly demands sex in parking lots, makes Colt wear her hosiery, and runs a blow-job clinic in the smoking garden of a local bar.

I am not offended by his pedantic diagrams of sexual positions, or by the character named Mlle Fuck-You. It’s the shrill, smug voice he picked up in college that I can’t stand. His narrator, The-Man-in-Love-with-the-Slut, describes himself as “your average spoiled white kid from the suburbs.”

“You are not a ‘white kid from the suburbs,’ ” I want to tell him. “You’re from a small town nowhere near a city. You were raised to treat people decently. And your father and I never spoiled you.” But I know—I know, I know—that this is not an autobiography.

I believe Colt when he tells me that in certain circles he is famous. Once I suggested that those circles might be concentrated in Brooklyn, and my throat closed with guilt the moment I said it. Colt is my delight; he is my only child. For nine months I prayed for the healthy heart now beating under his shirt. As soon as I could hold him, heart and all, I sensed the futility of prayer. I knew that every time he was hurt it would be my fault.


They smoked a joint right before dinner while I picked green beans from the garden. Colt’s elbows are on the table. He tells us, several times, that he would love it if some backwoods library in the Deep South banned his book.

“Enough about you,” Vivian says.

“Okay. Tell Mom about your new business idea,” he says.

“We have this dog park near our building, and the people are ridiculous. They dress the dogs in little quilted jackets. They give them the same kinds of names they give their kids: Jordan, Mason, Hunter, Taylor.”

“So ridiculous,” Colt says.

“Anyway, there’s a multilingual school down the street from the park. I thought maybe people would be into a multilingual class for dogs. Not like they think the dog is going to speak, but so a dog can follow commands in three or four languages.”

“You’re kidding, right?”

“I am, but I’m not. I think if we charged $75 per session, we might convince some people it’s worth paying for. So that might be my project for the next six months.” The look they exchange tells me this joke has been broken in, and that every time she tells it, Colt is charmed.

“What about you, Mom?” he says. “What do you see yourself doing in the next six months?”

“Maybe some camping up in Acadia before it gets too cold.” Georgia and I have been planning this trip for months.

“But who would go with you?”

“Yeah, who would go with you?”

They give me a pitying look. They think I am alone, and they think they are invincible. Vivian has no visible reaction to Colt’s hand on the back of her neck. This is the smugness of having your lover beside you all the time. I want to tell her that being loved this much leaves no mark. If Colt rises from the table, she will look as lonely as I do.


Sometimes I wish Colt would find the whole thing abhorrent. Two women? Disgusting. His own mother? Disgusting. If he could back away from it, maybe I could tell him. But Colt and Viv would levitate with pleasure. They’d sit there thinking they’d finally figured me out: there’s Mom, Judith, clear as an egg wash, a classic closet case. Maybe she’s been waiting for Georgia her whole life.

Surely Colt remembers the traffic jam. A westbound lane on the Sagamore Bridge, a cup of rum-raisin ice cream in his hand, his head out the window to watch the Cape Cod Canal churning with rain, traces of zinc oxide on his nose. He was eleven. He asked his parents, “Have either of you ever been in love?”

Oliver had just given me opal earrings for my birthday, suffered a lobster dinner on my behalf.

“Of course, son,” he said, reaching back to tousle his hair.

I couldn’t stop wondering why Colt would ask us that.

“He asks why we can’t take vacation on a different planet. He asks why we can’t drink saltwater. I wouldn’t worry about this,” Oliver said.

We were in the yard, the grass freshly mowed, mosquitoes biting freely as dusk unraveled. It was a Saturday, the night Oliver was allowed to get drunk. Colt was at a friend’s house, observing marriages that were apparently stronger than mine.

“Give me a priss, kitty,” Oliver said. “Stop worrying.”

I worried even more after that.


I can see it now: Georgia in a souvenir T-shirt, a shade overweight, telling stories as if we’ve been married for years. The three of them teasing me for voting Republican. “I always knew there was a liberal in there somewhere,” Colt will say. They will need a little less from me, a little more from each other; I in turn will need a little more from all of them.

They’ll have cocktail hour while I drink club soda with lime. Georgia will mix vodka and grenadine, even though I’ve told her it’s tacky. She doesn’t mind being teased, and she doesn’t know how to be jealous, two of my favorite things about her. She indulges me when I need to talk about my married life. She knows how many buttons I had on my wedding dress. She knows that Oliver and I spent our wedding night at the Pioneer Hotel, with its misplaced neoclassical columns. The windows were jalousies, and there was only one towel in the bathroom. There was a folding screen, and I’d felt obliged to change behind it, even though we’d seen each other naked many times.


I call Vivian to the bathroom after my shower. She is pleased. This is the kind of thing daughters-in-law do: they enter intimate spaces unflinchingly.

“Take a look at this mole,” I tell her, pulling my robe away from my breast. “I swear I didn’t have it this morning.”

She excuses herself to get her glasses from her handbag.

“That’s not a mole, Judith. That’s a tick.”

“It looks like a mole.”

“That’s because he’s in there pretty deep.”

“Well, shit,” I say. “Can you get it out?”

First she tries tweezers, which I keep on a mirrored tray by the sink.

“This fucker’s really in there,” she says.

My eyes are watery, my head hot.

“Do you think I might already have Lyme disease?”

“Don’t be ridiculous,” she says, the first hint of a mother I’ve ever seen in her.

When Vivian worries the tweezers are making it worse, she asks Colt to bring matches. There are holes in the knees of her jeans, and her fingernails are painted gold. She has a scar on her arm from breaking a window when her father refused to give her his credit card. (She was, she has assured me, only twenty-two at the time.) This is the girl who holds a flame close to my skin.

When she finally gets the tick out without starting a fire, I offer her fifty dollars. “An investment in your multilingual dog business.”

“Just watch for a bull’s-eye around the bite. If you see a bull’s-eye, we’ll need to go to the doctor in the morning,” she says.


I lie awake with all the lights on, watching for a bull’s-eye.

When Georgia can’t sleep, I comb her hair. When I can’t sleep, she tells me about her childhood. She has three older brothers. In their yard they had a set of dolphin-shaped swings that appeared to be caught by their chains. The Connecticut River sluiced the edge of their property. The swings were still there when Georgia drove me past the house this summer, but the place was dingy and run-down. One of the panes in the front door was sealed with a piece of cardboard, and someone had spray-painted the word keep on the side of the house.

“Oh, well,” Georgia said. “Maybe some college students live there now.”

I could be that calm too, if I’d never had to iron an impatient man’s shirt or peel a soft-boiled egg for a screaming child. I am not the kind of woman who complains about the life she was meant to have: I was supposed to be handling shirts and eggs. My husband was supposed to be faithful.

In the years I was tending to Colt and Oliver, Georgia was serving her family as the quirky unmarried one. She drove her nieces and nephews to zoos. She bought them geodes and suspended prisms in their windows. If she ever meets my son, she will become his cheerful aunt. She’s already read his novel twice.

“You need to introduce me to Colt soon,” she said recently. I was driving her home from the doctor’s office. “It’s kind of insulting.”

“Could you turn the AC down? It’s freezing in here.”

“You think I’m too nice to give you a hard time about this, don’t you.”

“No,” I said, but I laughed.

“I’m serious, Judith. I’m not afraid to piss you off.”

“Don’t I know it,” I said, but I am almost never mad at Georgia. It was Oliver who drew anger out of me. Oliver, capricious and unapologetic, a man who kept me guessing every day of our marriage.

When we were first dating, I couldn’t decide how to greet him. He never learned how to embrace. He let you press your body into his chest, but his arms were limp and useless. His firm handshake was so brief you couldn’t tell if his skin was warm. That was me: choosing between one of his hands and two of his arms, weighing the trade-off, wanting more than I could get.
story_a:
Judith had always found solace in routine. The morning light would filter through the lace curtains, casting delicate shadows on the kitchen floor as she brewed her coffee. The scent of freshly ground beans filled the air, mingling with the faint aroma of lavender from the garden. It was a small comfort, a daily ritual that anchored her amidst the chaos of a life recently upended by divorce.

Today, as she stood by the window, cradling her mug, Judith watched the world outside with a sense of detachment. The oak tree in her front yard, its branches swaying gently in the autumn breeze, seemed to mock her with its steadfastness. She sipped her coffee, letting the warmth seep into her bones, and wondered how everything had changed so quickly.

Her son, Ethan, had always been a quiet, introspective boy. Even now, as a grown man, there was an air of mystery about him that Judith could never quite penetrate. He had married young, to a woman named Lara, whose boldness and vivacity were a stark contrast to Ethan's reserved nature. Judith had never fully understood their dynamic, but she had accepted it, hoping that Lara's energy would draw Ethan out of his shell.

It was only after the divorce that Judith realized how little she truly knew her son. He had moved back in with her temporarily, bringing Lara with him. The house, once a sanctuary of calm, now buzzed with tension and unspoken words.

Judith had never been one for confrontation, preferring to let things lie rather than stir the pot. But living with Ethan and Lara had forced her to confront the cracks in their relationship, cracks that mirrored her own failed marriage. She could see the strain in the way Lara's eyes darted away when Ethan spoke, the way Ethan's shoulders tensed whenever Lara entered the room.

And then there was Georgia, the quirky neighbor who had moved in next door a few months ago. With her shock of curly red hair and penchant for eccentric clothing, Georgia was a breath of fresh air in Judith's otherwise staid existence. She had a way of seeing through Judith's carefully constructed facade, of piercing the veil of politeness that Judith wore like armor.

"Morning, Judith!" Georgia called from her porch, waving a brightly colored scarf in greeting. Judith smiled and waved back, feeling a pang of gratitude for the woman's relentless cheerfulness.

Georgia had an uncanny ability to appear just when Judith needed her most. Whether it was a spontaneous invitation for tea or a quick chat over the garden fence, Georgia's presence was a balm to Judith's wounded soul.

"Got any plans for the day?" Georgia asked, her voice carrying across the lawn.

Judith shook her head. "Just the usual, I suppose. Cleaning, cooking, trying to stay out of the way."

Georgia's eyes sparkled with mischief. "Why don't you come over for a bit? I've got a new batch of herbal tea I want you to try. It's supposed to be great for stress."

Judith hesitated, glancing back at the house. She could hear the faint murmur of Ethan and Lara's voices, muffled by the walls but still unmistakably strained. A part of her wanted to retreat, to bury herself in the familiar comfort of her routines. But another part, the part that had been slowly awakening since the divorce, urged her to step outside her comfort zone.

"Alright," she said, surprising herself with the firmness in her voice. "I'll be over in a few minutes."

Georgia beamed. "Great! I'll put the kettle on."

As Judith made her way next door, she couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation. It was a small thing, a simple visit to a neighbor, but it felt like a step toward something new, something different.

Georgia's house was a riot of color and eclectic decor, a stark contrast to Judith's own subdued home. The walls were adorned with vibrant tapestries and framed photographs, while the shelves overflowed with knick-knacks and mementos from Georgia's travels.

"Welcome to my humble abode," Georgia said with a flourish, leading Judith to the cozy kitchen nook. "Sit, sit! I'll get the tea."

Judith settled into a cushioned chair, taking in the whirlwind of sights and sounds around her. It was chaotic, but in a way that felt alive and invigorating.

"How are things at home?" Georgia asked, setting a steaming cup of tea in front of Judith.

Judith sighed, wrapping her hands around the warm mug. "Complicated, as always. Ethan and Lara... I don't know. I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around them."

Georgia nodded sympathetically. "Relationships are tricky, aren't they? Sometimes it feels like no matter what you do, you can't get it right."

Judith took a sip of the tea, savoring the soothing blend of herbs. "I just wish I knew how to help them. How to fix things."

"Maybe it's not about fixing," Georgia said gently. "Maybe it's about understanding. Sometimes, the best thing we can do is just be there, to listen and support without trying to solve everything."

Judith pondered Georgia's words, feeling a flicker of hope. Perhaps she had been going about it all wrong, trying to mend what was broken instead of simply being present.

"You're right," she said softly. "I've been so focused on trying to make things better that I haven't really been there for them."

Georgia smiled, reaching across the table to squeeze Judith's hand. "It's never too late to start."

Judith left Georgia's house with a renewed sense of purpose. She couldn't change the past, but she could be there for Ethan and Lara in the present. She could listen, support, and try to understand.

That evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, Judith found herself in the kitchen, preparing dinner. The rhythmic chopping of vegetables was a soothing balm to her frayed nerves. She could hear Ethan and Lara in the living room, their voices low and strained.

Taking a deep breath, Judith wiped her hands on a dish towel and made her way to the living room. Ethan looked up, surprise flickering in his eyes as she entered.

"Dinner will be ready soon," she said, her voice steady. "But I was hoping we could talk for a bit first."

Lara glanced at Ethan, then back at Judith. "Sure," she said cautiously.

Judith sat down, feeling the weight of the moment. "I know things have been difficult lately," she began, choosing her words carefully. "And I know I haven't been the best at supporting you both. But I want to change that. I want to be here for you, to listen and understand."

Ethan's gaze softened, and for the first time in weeks, Judith saw a glimmer of the boy she had raised, the boy who had once confided in her about his hopes and fears.

"It's not easy," Ethan said quietly. "Marriage, life... it's all so much harder than I thought it would be."

Lara nodded, her eyes filling with unshed tears. "We've been struggling, trying to make things work, but it feels like we're just drifting further apart."

Judith reached out, taking both their hands in hers. "You're not alone in this. We can figure it out together."

They talked long into the night, sharing their fears, frustrations, and hopes. It was a beginning, a tentative step toward healing and understanding.

In the days that followed, Judith made a conscious effort to be more present, to truly listen and support without trying to fix everything. It wasn't always easy, and there were still moments of tension and uncertainty. But there was also a growing sense of connection, a fragile but genuine bond that began to form between them.

One afternoon, as Judith worked in her garden, she felt a presence beside her. Looking up, she saw Georgia, her ever-present smile lighting up her face.

"How's it going?" Georgia asked, her eyes twinkling with curiosity.

Judith wiped the sweat from her brow, feeling a sense of accomplishment. "Better, I think. We're talking more, trying to understand each other. It's a slow process, but it feels like progress."

Georgia nodded approvingly. "That's wonderful to hear. Sometimes, it's the small steps that make the biggest difference."

Judith smiled, feeling a surge of gratitude for the woman who had become her friend and confidante. "Thank you, Georgia. For everything."

Georgia waved off her thanks with a laugh. "Oh, don't mention it. We're all just trying to figure this life thing out together, right?"

As the weeks turned into months, Judith found herself growing more comfortable with the new rhythm of her life. She discovered strength she hadn't known she possessed, a resilience that carried her through the challenges she faced.

Ethan and Lara continued to navigate their own struggles, but there was a newfound openness between them. They began attending couples therapy, working through their issues with a determination that both impressed and humbled Judith.

One evening, as they sat around the dinner table, Lara reached for Judith's hand. "Thank you," she said, her voice filled with sincerity. "For being there for us, for believing in us."

Judith felt a lump form in her throat, her heart swelling with emotion. "I'm so proud of you both," she said, her voice trembling. "You've come so far, and I know you'll continue to grow together."

Ethan squeezed her hand, his eyes shining with gratitude. "We couldn't have done it without you, Mom."

As they shared a meal, laughter and conversation filling the air, Judith felt a sense of peace she hadn't known in a long time. The road ahead was still uncertain, but she knew they would face it together, with love and understanding guiding their way.

Later that night, as she lay in bed, Judith reflected on the journey she had taken since her divorce. It had been a difficult and often painful path, but it had also been a journey of self-discovery and growth. She had found strength in herself and in the connections she had forged with those around her.

And as she drifted off to sleep, the gentle rustle of the oak tree outside her window a comforting lullaby, Judith knew that she was exactly where she was meant to be.
story_b:
Judith stood at the window, watching the early morning light pour over her garden. The garden was a recent endeavor, a patch of earth she could control and watch grow. The soil was rich and dark, a canvas upon which she could project her hopes and fears. Her heart, she mused, felt like a compass spinning wildly, seeking true north but never quite settling. It was still adjusting to the absence of her husband, the man who had been her constant companion for over thirty years.

The divorce had been amicable, as amicable as such things could be. They had simply grown apart, their lives diverging like two paths in the woods, each veering off into its own direction. Now, she was left to navigate the tangled web of her new life, her relationships unspooling in unexpected ways.

Her son, David, and his wife, Claire, were her closest family. Yet, Judith often felt like an outsider in their vibrant world. Claire was bold, full of opinions and energy, her laughter echoing through their home like wind chimes in a storm. She challenged Judith's views on independence and family, sometimes with a sharpness that cut through Judith's carefully constructed defenses. But there was love there, too—a fierce, protective love that Judith envied and admired.

Then there was Georgia, the neighbor who had arrived shortly after the divorce, her entrance as sudden and colorful as a firework in the night sky. Georgia was everything Judith was not—quirky, spontaneous, and unfiltered. She spoke in riddles and metaphors, her words a tapestry woven from dreams and reality. Despite—or perhaps because of—her eccentricities, Judith found comfort in Georgia’s presence, a connection she hadn’t realized she needed.

Judith turned from the window, the scent of fresh paint mingling with the aroma of baked bread. She was renovating her home, stripping it down to its bones and rebuilding it, much like she was doing with her life. The walls echoed with the laughter of family gatherings past, a reminder of both comfort and confinement.

The doorbell rang, pulling Judith from her reverie. She opened the door to find David and Claire, their faces flushed from the cold. Claire carried a basket of fresh produce, her cheeks pink and her eyes alight with mischief.

“Mom!” David exclaimed, wrapping her in a warm embrace. His scent, a mix of pine and something distinctly him, filled her senses. “We brought some goodies from the market.”

Judith stepped aside, allowing them in. “It smells wonderful in here,” Claire remarked, setting the basket on the counter. “Renovations going well?”

Judith nodded, glancing around at the half-painted walls and the sheets covering the furniture. “Slow but steady. It’s a work in progress, just like me.”

Claire laughed, a sound like a bell. “Aren’t we all?”

They settled into the kitchen, the conversation flowing as easily as the coffee Judith poured. Yet, beneath the surface, Judith felt the familiar tug of isolation. It was as if she were standing on the edge of a family photograph, her presence acknowledged but somehow peripheral.

“Have you given any more thought to traveling with us this summer?” David asked, breaking into her thoughts.

Judith hesitated, the idea of joining them on their adventures both thrilling and terrifying. Claire’s gaze was penetrating, as if she could see into Judith’s very soul. “It could be fun,” Claire suggested. “A chance to explore and maybe even find a new direction.”

Judith forced a smile. “I’ll think about it.”

After they left, the silence of the house enveloped her. She wandered back to the window, her eyes drawn to the garden. A movement caught her attention—Georgia, kneeling among the plants, her hands deep in the soil. Judith watched her for a moment, admiring the way Georgia seemed to converse with the earth, her touch gentle and knowing.

Judith stepped outside, the crisp air carrying the scent of autumn. Georgia looked up, her face breaking into a wide grin. “Judith! Come join me. The garden’s got secrets to share today.”

Judith chuckled, kneeling beside her. “What kind of secrets?”

Georgia’s eyes twinkled. “The kind that grow in the dark and bloom in the light. Just like us, don’t you think?”

They worked in companionable silence, the soil cool and forgiving beneath their fingers. Judith found solace in the rhythm of planting, the act of nurturing life a balm for her restless heart.

“Your son and his wife seem lovely,” Georgia remarked, her voice light but probing.

“They are,” Judith agreed, her mind drifting back to David and Claire. “It’s just…sometimes I feel like I’m intruding in their lives. Like I’m not quite sure where I fit anymore.”

Georgia nodded, her expression thoughtful. “Families are like gardens. They need tending, but they also need space to grow on their own. You’ll find your place, Judith. Sometimes it just takes time.”

Judith pondered Georgia’s words, the metaphor settling over her like a warm blanket. She had been so focused on what she had lost, she hadn’t truly considered what she might gain.

Over the following weeks, Judith found herself drawn more and more to her garden, and to Georgia. They shared stories and secrets, Georgia’s quirky insights challenging Judith’s long-held beliefs. It was in these moments that Judith felt a stirring of something new—a sense of belonging not tethered to her past, but rooted in the present.

One stormy night, as rain lashed the windows and thunder rumbled overhead, Judith sat with Georgia in her cozy living room. The fire crackled, casting flickering shadows across the walls.

“The sky’s weeping with you,” Georgia said softly, her gaze fixed on the storm outside. “But remember, Judith, every storm passes. And when it does, the air is clearer, the world refreshed.”

Judith nodded, her heart heavy with the weight of her emotions. “I just feel so lost sometimes.”

“You’re not lost,” Georgia insisted. “You’re exploring. And there’s a difference.”

Judith let the words sink in, the truth of them resonating deep within her. She realized that her journey wasn’t about finding her old self, but discovering who she was now—beyond the roles of wife and mother, beyond the expectations she had set for herself.

The next morning, the storm had passed, leaving the world washed and new. Judith stood at her window, the garden glistening in the early sunlight. She felt a shift within her, a subtle realignment of priorities and desires.

She called David, her voice steady and clear. “About that trip… I’d like to join you and Claire this summer.”

His response was immediate, his joy evident. “That’s wonderful, Mom! It’ll be an adventure.”

After the call, Judith stepped into the garden, her fingers brushing the leaves and petals, each touch grounding her in the here and now. She had spent so long feeling adrift, but now she sensed the solid earth beneath her feet, the promise of growth and renewal.

Her heart, once a compass spinning wildly, had found its true north.

As summer approached, Judith embraced the changes in her life with a newfound confidence. Her relationship with David and Claire flourished, each interaction bringing them closer. She cherished the candid conversations they shared, the laughter and understanding that bridged the gaps between them.

story_a:
"That was a simple curse for our interrogation, you can no longer lie."

I blinked at the sorceress, feeling a twinge of panic. "That is evil, especially because I lie so often, like when I said your shirt looked nice but I actually thought it was ugly as hell."

She raised an eyebrow, her lips curling into an amused smirk. "Oversharing is not a part of the curse, that is just you."

I grimaced, realizing that my mouth had a mind of its own now. The curse had stripped away the thin veil of social niceties I’d always hidden behind, leaving me raw and exposed. I glanced around the dimly lit chamber, its stone walls adorned with flickering torches casting ominous shadows. The air smelled of dampness and old magic.

The sorceress, Elara, leaned closer, her eyes narrowing. "Now, tell me, where is the Amulet of Aranthor?"

I felt a sharp pang of dread as the compulsion to speak the truth surged through me. "I don’t know."

Her expression darkened. "Lies won't work here, remember?"

"I’m not lying," I blurted out. "I really don’t know where it is. I was only hired to distract you while my partner retrieved it."

Elara's eyes widened slightly, a flicker of surprise crossing her face. She hadn’t expected me to be so forthcoming, and honestly, neither had I. But the curse was relentless, dragging every morsel of honesty to the surface.

"And where is your partner now?" she demanded.

I sighed, my shoulders slumping. "Probably halfway to the border by now. We had a plan to meet at the old mill just outside of town. I was supposed to stall you for as long as possible."

Elara’s jaw tightened, her fingers drumming impatiently on the wooden table between us. "Who is your partner? Give me a name."

"His name is Jareth," I said, feeling the words tumble out against my will. "He’s a master thief, much better at this than I am."

Her eyes gleamed with satisfaction. "Thank you for your cooperation. You’ve been surprisingly helpful."

My face flushed with frustration and helplessness. "I didn’t want to help you. I hate this curse. It’s like my brain and my mouth are disconnected."

Elara chuckled softly, standing up from her chair. "Consider it a lesson. Perhaps you’ll think twice before getting involved in matters beyond your understanding."

"Yeah, yeah," I muttered, glancing down at the table. "Just get it over with. I know what comes next."

She paused, her expression softening ever so slightly. "Actually, I have another idea."

I looked up, confusion etched on my face. "What do you mean?"

Elara walked around the table, her footsteps echoing in the chamber. "You’ve given me valuable information, and for that, I’m willing to offer you a deal."

"A deal?" I repeated skeptically. "What kind of deal?"

"I'll lift the curse," she said, her voice calm and measured. "In return, you will help me retrieve the Amulet of Aranthor and bring Jareth to justice."

I stared at her, my mind racing. Betraying Jareth wasn’t part of the plan, but the thought of being free from this curse was tempting. "And if I refuse?"

"Then you’ll remain cursed," she said simply, "and I’ll ensure that your life becomes very uncomfortable."

I clenched my fists, weighing my options. There was no way I could live like this, constantly spilling my guts without control. I took a deep breath, feeling the weight of the decision. "Fine. I’ll help you."

Elara nodded, a faint smile playing on her lips. "Good choice. Now, let’s lift that curse."

She muttered an incantation, her hands weaving intricate patterns in the air. I felt a tingling sensation wash over me, and suddenly, the compulsion to speak the truth was gone. I sighed in relief, my mind finally at ease.

"Thank you," I said, my voice steady. "So, what’s the plan?"

Elara’s eyes sparkled with determination. "We’ll head to the old mill and intercept Jareth. With your help, we’ll retrieve the amulet and put an end to his schemes."

I nodded, feeling a sense of resolve building within me. "Alright, let’s do this."

As we left the chamber and made our way through the winding corridors of the castle, I couldn’t help but feel a strange sense of camaraderie with Elara. Despite our initial confrontation, we were now bound by a common goal. The night was dark and full of uncertainties, but for the first time, I felt a glimmer of hope.

We reached the castle gates, the cool night air brushing against our faces. Elara glanced at me, her expression serious. "Remember, this won’t be easy. Jareth is cunning and dangerous."

"I know," I replied, determination in my voice. "But we’ll get that amulet back."

With that, we set off into the night, ready to face the challenges ahead. The path was uncertain, but I was no longer alone. Together, we would confront the lies and deceit, and perhaps, find a way to weave truth into the heart of our journey.

The interrogator raised an eyebrow. “Oversharing is not a part of the curse, that is just you.”

I groaned, feeling the weight of the curse settling in. The room around me was stark and clinical, the cold metal chair I was strapped to only adding to my discomfort. The fluorescent light above flickered intermittently, casting harsh shadows across the room. My mind raced, trying to find a way out of this mess.

“Why am I here?” I asked, my voice trembling slightly.

The interrogator, a tall man with a stern expression and piercing blue eyes, leaned forward. “You’re here because you have information we need. Information you’ve been hiding.”

I swallowed hard. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Lies won’t work on me anymore,” he said, a cruel smile playing on his lips. “So, let’s start with something simple. What’s your name?”

I opened my mouth to lie, but the curse kicked in. “Evelyn,” I muttered, cursing myself internally. 

“Good. Now, what were you doing at the docks last night?”

My mind flashed back to the previous night, the clandestine meeting, the exchange of information. I tried to resist, but the curse forced the truth out of me. “I was meeting with a contact. We were discussing plans for an upcoming operation.”

The interrogator’s smile widened. “See, that wasn’t so hard, was it?”

I clenched my fists, the restraints biting into my skin. “You have no idea what you’re doing,” I spat. “This curse... it’s not just about lying. It’s about control.”

He leaned back in his chair, studying me. “Tell me more.”

I hesitated, but the words spilled out of me regardless. “It’s not just that I can’t lie. It’s that I can’t stop talking. Everything, every little thought, it just... comes out.”

His eyes gleamed with interest. “Interesting. So, you’re saying that this curse not only prevents you from lying but also compels you to speak the truth at all times?”

“Yes,” I said through gritted teeth. “And it’s driving me insane.”

The interrogator stood up and walked around the room, his footsteps echoing off the walls. “Well, Evelyn, I think we’re going to have a very productive session.”

I watched him warily as he approached a table covered in various interrogation tools. He picked up a small, silver device and turned it over in his hands. “Do you know what this is?”

I shook my head, my heart pounding in my chest.

“This is a truth serum,” he said, holding it up for me to see. “But given your current predicament, I don’t think we’ll need it.”

He set the device back down and returned to his chair. “Now, let’s get to the heart of the matter. Who are you working for?”

The answer was on the tip of my tongue, but I fought to keep it in. The curse, however, had other plans. “The Resistance,” I blurted out, feeling a surge of panic.

“Excellent,” the interrogator said, leaning forward once more. “And what is your role within the Resistance?”

“I’m a strategist,” I said, unable to stop myself. “I plan operations, coordinate with other cells, gather intelligence.”

He nodded, taking notes on a small pad of paper. “And what are your current plans?”

I bit my lip, trying to hold back, but it was no use. “We’re planning a raid on the government’s weapons depot. We need supplies, and it’s the only way to get them.”

The interrogator’s eyes narrowed. “When is this raid supposed to take place?”

My mind screamed at me to stop, but the curse forced the words out. “Tomorrow night. Midnight.”

He smiled, satisfied with the information. “Thank you, Evelyn. You’ve been very helpful.”

I slumped in my chair, feeling defeated. The curse had stripped me of my ability to resist, to protect my comrades. I had betrayed them all with my uncontrollable honesty.

The interrogator stood up and walked to the door, opening it slightly. “Guards, take her back to her cell,” he ordered.

Two burly guards entered the room and unstrapped me from the chair. They led me down a long, dimly lit corridor, the walls lined with doors leading to other interrogation rooms. I could hear the faint sounds of other prisoners being questioned, their cries of pain and desperation echoing through the hall.

As we walked, my mind raced, trying to come up with a plan. I couldn’t let the Resistance’s plans be thwarted because of me. I needed to warn them, to find a way to communicate the danger.

The guards threw me into a small, windowless cell and slammed the door shut. I sat on the cold, hard floor, my thoughts swirling in a chaotic mess. The silence was deafening, and my thoughts were my only company.

I don’t know how long I sat there, my mind drifting in and out of focus. Time seemed to stretch and warp, the minutes blending into hours. The curse weighed heavily on me, the compulsion to speak the truth gnawing at my sanity.

Just when I thought I couldn’t take it anymore, the door to my cell creaked open. A figure stepped inside, cloaked in shadow. I squinted, trying to make out their features.

“Evelyn,” a familiar voice whispered. “It’s me.”

My heart leaped in my chest. It was Marcus, one of my closest friends and a fellow member of the Resistance. “Marcus, how did you find me?”

He knelt beside me, his eyes filled with concern. “We have our ways. Are you okay?”

“No,” I admitted, feeling the curse compel me to speak. “I’m not okay. I told them everything, Marcus. The raid, our plans... everything.”

He placed a reassuring hand on my shoulder. “It’s not your fault, Evelyn. We know about the curse. That’s why we’re here.”

I looked at him, hope flickering in my chest. “What do you mean?”

“We’re here to get you out,” he said, a determined glint in his eyes. “And to stop the raid. We can’t let them win.”

Tears welled up in my eyes as I realized I wasn’t alone. Despite the curse, despite my betrayal, my friends hadn’t given up on me. “Thank you,” I whispered.

He smiled, helping me to my feet. “Let’s go. We have work to do.”

As we made our way out of the facility, I felt a renewed sense of purpose. The curse may have taken away my ability to lie, but it hadn’t taken away my resolve. We would fight back, and we would win.

And this time, I wouldn’t let anything stand in our way.

"Yes," I finally said, my voice barely above a whisper. "I regret it. But I don't know how to live any other way."

The interrogator leaned back, his eyes boring into mine. "This curse," he said slowly, "it could be a blessing in disguise. A chance to start over, to be honest for once in your life."

I snorted, the bitterness rising again. "Honesty is overrated. People say they want the truth, but they can't handle it. Lies are what keep the world spinning, what keep us sane."

The interrogator's gaze softened, and for a moment, I saw a flicker of understanding. "Perhaps," he said quietly. "But now, you have no choice."

The silence that followed was oppressive, the weight of my confession hanging in the air. I could feel the curse pulsing within me, a constant reminder of my newfound honesty. It was a prison of my own making, one that I couldn't escape.

"What's next?" I asked, my voice hollow.

The interrogator stood, gathering his notes. "Next, you face the consequences," he said simply. "But remember, this is also an opportunity. Use it wisely."

He left the room, the door closing with a finality that echoed in my soul. I was alone, the silence pressing in on me from all sides. The curse was a constant presence, a reminder that I could no longer hide behind my lies.

I thought about my past, the web of deceit I'd woven to protect myself. Each lie had been a thread, binding me tighter and tighter until I could no longer breathe. Now, those threads were unraveling, leaving me exposed and vulnerable.

But maybe, just maybe, the interrogator was right. Perhaps this curse was a chance to start over, to face my demons and find a new way to live. It was a terrifying thought, one that filled me with both dread and hope.

As I sat in that sterile, cold room, I made a silent promise to myself. I would try. I would face the truth, no matter how painful it might be. The future was uncertain, and the path ahead was shrouded in darkness. But for the first time in my life, I would walk it with honesty, one step at a time.

And maybe, just maybe, I would find a way to heal.
