""Oh, I'm fully aware." I said with a vicious smile. "You'll know everything I say is 100% full unvarnished truth."

"Where are the other terrorists?" She said, staying as calm as a statue.

"Oh, I don't know any terrorists. See for us to qualify as terrorists we need to be using fear to enact change and we're just trying to kill that fake-ass not a king. We're not terrorists. We're assassins. Also your breath smells bad."

"...where are the other assassins?" she asked, her hand didn't even twitch to check how rancid her breath smelled even though she must desperately want to.

"I've been here the last 2 days hanging out with you and the dumbass brigade who I have to say are not quite as smart as I thought they'd be, as a collective, I mean I knew they weren't always smart because the smart ones tend to get killed for figuring out leader McBitchyPissy the 3rd's antics. That being said, it's nice to know at least one of you has a heart."

Oh, she twitched at that.

"Which of the officers expressed sympathy at you?"

"The one in uniform, of course. I mean really, it's more surprising you're not asking me about the little antics your boss gets-OH you help him! Oh, that's some real kinky shit, if it's true. Did you watch or were you just standing guard? WAIT! Don't tell me.... I really want to know, but I'm scared you'll say you weren't involved. Damn, this stuff really does work. And it's not like me and my friends wouldn't see some."

"... we'll circle back to the potential traitor at another-" 

"You should have said 'traitor later'."

"..."

"It rhymes."

"...another time. You don't know where your fellow assassins are."

"Thank you for not calling me a terrorist. It really means a lot to me.... for some reason. Probably because I think the terrorists don't care about infrastructure and assassins are really a lot more clean, even though there's definitely going to be a deadly civil war after we kill the king. You'll probably die in it. Or at least the person who cut your hair. Do you think they deserve it? Because I don't, but I do think some form of punishment is warranted."

"...where is the most likely place your fellow assassins would be?"

"I think they'll probably be in dreamland. If I'm keeping time right and that clock is telling the truth, I know I should be keeping track on my own, but it's hard. I know it's day but there's nothing wrong with catching a few extra hours so you can better topple a tyrant."

"Where do they feel safe enough to rest?"

"Probably nowhere if we're being honest. The king started hunting them before they actually committed any crimes! Did you know that? The king hunts people? DON'T LOOK AWAY FROM ME!" I scream at her.

"You know they don't feel safe?" I smile.

"...Where would they most likely rest before a mission?"

"I never did the full counting of all the places we had to stay to avoid being murdered, so I can't really say which is the most likely. Almost like it'd be easier to kill the king rather than leave the city. Hey! Look at that, I really do think that. I wasn't always sure but this is actually really helpful. I wonder if they could do this with therapy! It'd make things go so much faster. And let's face it, all the blood on my hands? I'll definitely need it. I assume you must take a hit of this every now and then, or does suppressing all the blood on your hands mean you can't? I'm sure you've killed at least a dozen, right? And they definitely didn't deserve it."

".........Give me detailed directions to the last ten places you stayed together.

"We take a step. Then a step. Then a step. Then a step. Then a step. Then-"

"Stop."

"I'm always willing to help people who deserve it. But I'm not really one to help someone so out of control of their own moral code."

"By your own admission, you're going to start a war."

"And you know this is evil. Let's face it, when he goes it's gonna happen anyway. Oh wow, that's a dark thought. I guess I really do think that. What else do I think? Yogurt is better than cereal. Moldy bread tastes better than fresh. I picked my teeth with a tiny blade I keep in my sleeve. HEY YEAH!" I scream out I swing around in an arc as I lift myself up."

The table flips up. I feel my bonds fall apart. The investigator leaps and draws her gun.

In two seconds, the dagger is at her throat, her gun lays un-fired at my feet as I hold one arm with a hand.

"Isn't this interesting? I think it is. I've never held someone hostage before."

"You'll never get away with this."

"I think I will. I wouldn't do it otherwise. Besides, you'll stay quiet."

"I am a loyal-"

"I know. Loyal to the country. Not to him. That's what I liked about you. You have a heart. Despite the bad fashion sense and halitosis." I grin. "Don't worry, I don't need to kill you. So I shan't until I ... whah-nt? Gotta be better rhymes." I stand and crack my back.

"Goodbye Inspector." I said as I opened the door. "Hope I see you again soon."

And then under my breath, "And I really hope you see a doctor about that breath."
story_a:
"That was a simple curse for our interrogation, you can no longer lie."

I blinked at the sorceress, feeling a twinge of panic. "That is evil, especially because I lie so often, like when I said your shirt looked nice but I actually thought it was ugly as hell."

She raised an eyebrow, her lips curling into an amused smirk. "Oversharing is not a part of the curse, that is just you."

I grimaced, realizing that my mouth had a mind of its own now. The curse had stripped away the thin veil of social niceties I’d always hidden behind, leaving me raw and exposed. I glanced around the dimly lit chamber, its stone walls adorned with flickering torches casting ominous shadows. The air smelled of dampness and old magic.

The sorceress, Elara, leaned closer, her eyes narrowing. "Now, tell me, where is the Amulet of Aranthor?"

I felt a sharp pang of dread as the compulsion to speak the truth surged through me. "I don’t know."

Her expression darkened. "Lies won't work here, remember?"

"I’m not lying," I blurted out. "I really don’t know where it is. I was only hired to distract you while my partner retrieved it."

Elara's eyes widened slightly, a flicker of surprise crossing her face. She hadn’t expected me to be so forthcoming, and honestly, neither had I. But the curse was relentless, dragging every morsel of honesty to the surface.

"And where is your partner now?" she demanded.

I sighed, my shoulders slumping. "Probably halfway to the border by now. We had a plan to meet at the old mill just outside of town. I was supposed to stall you for as long as possible."

Elara’s jaw tightened, her fingers drumming impatiently on the wooden table between us. "Who is your partner? Give me a name."

"His name is Jareth," I said, feeling the words tumble out against my will. "He’s a master thief, much better at this than I am."

Her eyes gleamed with satisfaction. "Thank you for your cooperation. You’ve been surprisingly helpful."

My face flushed with frustration and helplessness. "I didn’t want to help you. I hate this curse. It’s like my brain and my mouth are disconnected."

Elara chuckled softly, standing up from her chair. "Consider it a lesson. Perhaps you’ll think twice before getting involved in matters beyond your understanding."

"Yeah, yeah," I muttered, glancing down at the table. "Just get it over with. I know what comes next."

She paused, her expression softening ever so slightly. "Actually, I have another idea."

I looked up, confusion etched on my face. "What do you mean?"

Elara walked around the table, her footsteps echoing in the chamber. "You’ve given me valuable information, and for that, I’m willing to offer you a deal."

"A deal?" I repeated skeptically. "What kind of deal?"

"I'll lift the curse," she said, her voice calm and measured. "In return, you will help me retrieve the Amulet of Aranthor and bring Jareth to justice."

I stared at her, my mind racing. Betraying Jareth wasn’t part of the plan, but the thought of being free from this curse was tempting. "And if I refuse?"

"Then you’ll remain cursed," she said simply, "and I’ll ensure that your life becomes very uncomfortable."

I clenched my fists, weighing my options. There was no way I could live like this, constantly spilling my guts without control. I took a deep breath, feeling the weight of the decision. "Fine. I’ll help you."

Elara nodded, a faint smile playing on her lips. "Good choice. Now, let’s lift that curse."

She muttered an incantation, her hands weaving intricate patterns in the air. I felt a tingling sensation wash over me, and suddenly, the compulsion to speak the truth was gone. I sighed in relief, my mind finally at ease.

"Thank you," I said, my voice steady. "So, what’s the plan?"

Elara’s eyes sparkled with determination. "We’ll head to the old mill and intercept Jareth. With your help, we’ll retrieve the amulet and put an end to his schemes."

I nodded, feeling a sense of resolve building within me. "Alright, let’s do this."

As we left the chamber and made our way through the winding corridors of the castle, I couldn’t help but feel a strange sense of camaraderie with Elara. Despite our initial confrontation, we were now bound by a common goal. The night was dark and full of uncertainties, but for the first time, I felt a glimmer of hope.

We reached the castle gates, the cool night air brushing against our faces. Elara glanced at me, her expression serious. "Remember, this won’t be easy. Jareth is cunning and dangerous."

"I know," I replied, determination in my voice. "But we’ll get that amulet back."

With that, we set off into the night, ready to face the challenges ahead. The path was uncertain, but I was no longer alone. Together, we would confront the lies and deceit, and perhaps, find a way to weave truth into the heart of our journey.
story_b:
As soon as the words left the interrogator's lips, I felt a strange tingle in my throat, like a truth serum had just been injected into my veins. My eyes widened as the realization hit me—this was going to be a disaster.

"That is evil, especially because I lie so often, like when I said your shirt looked nice but I actually thought it was ugly as hell." The words tumbled out before I could stop them, my mouth seemingly disconnected from my brain. The interrogator raised an eyebrow, a bemused smile playing on his lips.

"Oversharing is not a part of the curse, that is just you," he remarked, clearly enjoying my predicament. 

I groaned internally. My life was built on a carefully constructed web of little white lies. How was I supposed to navigate a world where honesty was my only option? My mind raced through the implications as I left the interrogation room, the door clicking shut behind me.

The first hurdle came almost immediately. I bumped into Karen, my overly inquisitive colleague, in the hallway. She was infamous for her daily barrage of questions about everything from work to my personal life.

"Hey! How was your weekend?" she chirped, her eyes bright with curiosity.

I opened my mouth to respond, and before I could even think, "I spent the weekend binge-watching reality TV and eating an entire tub of ice cream," slipped out. My eyes widened as Karen giggled, a knowing smirk on her face.

"Oh, sounds productive," she teased, clearly relishing my discomfort.

I hurried away, my face burning with embarrassment. This was only the beginning, I realized with a sinking feeling.

By lunchtime, the curse had already wreaked havoc. My friend Mike and I were sitting in the cafeteria, and he asked me what I thought of his new haircut. It was a disaster—a lopsided mess of uneven strands that looked like it had been styled by a blindfolded toddler.

"It's terrible," I blurted out, my hand flying to my mouth in shock. Mike's face fell, and I scrambled to recover. "But, uh, it's really... unique?"

Mike chuckled, shaking his head. "Well, at least you're honest," he said, though his eyes betrayed a hint of hurt.

The afternoon dragged on, each interaction a minefield of potential truth bombs. By the time I got home, I was exhausted from the effort of not speaking. I collapsed onto the couch, hoping for some respite from my newfound honesty.

But the universe had other plans. My phone buzzed with a text from my sister, asking me to babysit my nephew the next day. Normally, I would have concocted some excuse about being too busy, but now...

"Sure, I'd love to!" I typed back, internally cursing myself for the enthusiastic punctuation. Babysitting was not my idea of a fun time, but the curse had left me no choice.

The next morning, I arrived at my sister's house, greeted by the chaos of a toddler's world. Toys were strewn across the floor, and my nephew, Max, was running around with boundless energy.

"Uncle!" he squealed, barreling into my legs with a force that nearly toppled me over.

"Hey, buddy," I said, ruffling his hair. His wide-eyed innocence was a refreshing change from the tangled web of adult interactions.

As the day wore on, I found myself enjoying Max's company more than I expected. He had no need for lies or pretense, living in a world of pure, unfiltered truth. It was both terrifying and liberating.

"Why is your hair like that?" Max asked suddenly, his tiny fingers pointing at my head.

I laughed, the sound surprising me. "Because I haven't had a chance to cut it," I admitted, realizing how freeing it felt to be honest with someone who didn't judge.

By the time my sister returned, I was sprawled on the floor, surrounded by toys and giggling uncontrollably with Max. She raised an eyebrow at the sight, clearly taken aback.

"Wow, I didn't expect you to be having so much fun," she remarked, a note of surprise in her voice.

I grinned, the curse momentarily forgotten. "Turns out, honesty isn't so bad when you're around someone who doesn't care about appearances."

As I drove home, the weight of the curse felt lighter, like I'd found a loophole in its strict grasp. Maybe there was something to be gained from this enforced honesty after all.

The following day, I walked into work with a newfound sense of clarity. The curse was still there, lurking beneath the surface, but I felt more equipped to handle its challenges.

Karen accosted me again, her eyes twinkling with mischief. "So, did you do anything exciting yesterday?" she asked.

I smiled, ready for her this time. "I babysat my nephew, and it was actually... really fun," I replied, a genuine warmth in my voice.

Karen's expression softened, and she nodded approvingly. "See? Being honest isn't the end of the world."

I continued through the day, navigating conversations with a mix of caution and curiosity. The curse had forced me to confront my own fears about honesty, peeling back layers of social niceties that had once felt necessary.

By the time I got home, I felt a strange sense of accomplishment. The curse hadn't disappeared, but I'd learned to live with it, embracing the chaos it brought. Maybe my life didn't need to be built on white lies and half-truths.

As I settled onto the couch, my phone buzzed with a message from Mike.

"Thanks for being honest about my haircut. I got it fixed today. Drinks on me?"

I chuckled, typing back a quick response. The curse had been a catalyst, forcing me to reassess what mattered and what didn't. In the end, I realized that honesty, while brutal, had its perks—like finally getting my boss to admit he hated his own tie collection.

prompt: Two lifelong friends, bound by love yet divided by irreconcilable beliefs, find themselves in a dream where one must deliver an urgent message to the other—but an abyss, a wall, and the weight of their differences stand in the way.
ground_truth:
“Iforget,” Ilka says to the friends around the table. “Do we allow ourselves to tell our dreams?”

“You have a good one?” Bessie asks her.

“You know the kind of movie in which something has to be prevented? In this dream, there is some fatal thing I need urgently to say to my cousin Frieda, but she is on the far side of an abyss, and then she is on the other side of a wall.”

“What’s the urgent thing you need to say to her?”

“The dream doesn’t specify.”

The friends, who have been meeting for lunch for some thirty years, live in a fifteen-block area on the Upper West Side. They talk the politics you expect on the Upper West Side of New York, except when Ilka is talking to them about her cousin Frieda Fishgoppel, professor of philosophy, now emerita.

Ilka says, “The dream is something to do with our most recent reconciliation.”

“Why reconcile when you know that you will keep quarrelling?” Farah asks.

“Our project,” Ilka says, “is to be reconciled to quarrelling.”

“But why do you keep the argument going?” asks Ruth, the bona-fide retired activist. “You disagree with everything she stands for and disbelieve what she believes.”

“And believe,” Ilka says, “in her inalienable right to believe what I disagree with. It’s in the nature, on my part certainly, of a demonstration, proof that we live in a democracy where people—and people we love—may have different, have wrong, opinions.”

“And she is game to let you keep disagreeing?” asks Bridget.

“Nnnnno,” Ilka says rather slowly. “But I like, I love, the intelligible, passionate language in which she disagrees. Frieda is in love with her truths in a way I do not love mine. And you all know that she was my ticket to America—my old ur-story.”

“Tell it again,” the friends say, and settle themselves on their chairs.

“After the end of the war,” Ilka says, “Frieda searched for the western, Viennese branch of our family. The generation of the grandparents who weren’t dead of old age had been killed in the camps, but there were cousins who had emigrated to Uruguay, to Paraguay, to the Dominican Republic, to Argentina. An uncle went to Canada. Frieda sent the visa for me to come to New York. She settled me in her funny little apartment in Washington Heights—in the fifties, there were so many of us we called it Washingstein Heights. She handed me an Oxford English Dictionary and hurried back to New Haven for her exams. She would come in to see if I was O.K., bring me ‘David Copperfield’ or a Jane Austen. I had arrived speaking minimal English, but all the refugees were soon reading novels in English, though maybe not the Henry James that Frieda brought me.”

“What was her field?” Ruth asks.

“Frieda’s first Ph.D. was in literature, and her dissertation was about antisemitism in her favorite writings from—I don’t exactly remember—was it ‘Beowulf’ to Eliot?

“Frieda and I still e-mail. If we don’t hear from each other, we worry. ‘The earth is flat and has four sharp corners,’ she writes me. ‘It’s easy to drop off the edge.’ She has not replied to my last, and so I promptly assume that she has fallen! She is in emergency! Or, this time, did I go too far?”

Crossword Puzzles with a Side of Millennial Socialism


“But what about?’’ Bridget asks.

“I’m trying to remember—what were we saying on the bus in Jerusalem?” Ilka muses. “Frieda and I were travelling with a group of Americans—that was in the eighties. We were sitting, talking, and she remembers that I got up and walked away and that I got off the bus. I remember that we did not talk for the last leg of the trip. We didn’t get together back in New York until Lotte invited both of us to dinner. She left us in a room together with the door shut, and Frieda and I started to laugh. You and I, we said to each other, we don’t have to go on doing this. You know what I will say, and I know what you are going to answer. But to this day we are still arguing the same opposing politics without having made a dent in each other’s opinion.”

“Her wrong opinion, which leads her to vote on the wrong side,” Ruth says.

“Which she believes to be the right side as fully as she believes that yours and mine is wrong.”

“And you know the disastrous consequences of hers,” Ruth says.

“That’s why I walked off the bus, I suppose,” says Ilka.

“But you go on talking.”

“We go on talking.”

Bridget says, “You keep not telling us what you argue about.”

“Because I am more interested in the fact, the nature, of disagreement,” Ilka says. “Also, it keeps the conversation from going to Israel, though Frieda says, correctly I think, that ‘to not go there’ is to silence speech.”

Ruth asks, “So exactly what is the dispute?”

Ilka says, “One way of putting it is that I choose to think of myself as a humanist, a child of Adam, where Frieda thinks of herself as a child of God-chosen Abraham. The DNA, as she says, will be the same.

“I search for what Isaac, the progenitor of Israel, has in common with his brother Ishmael, progenitor of Canaan: They both laugh if you tickle them and bleed when you prick them, which drives poor Frieda frantic. She says Shakespeare probably never met a Jew in his life. She challenges—no, she demolishes—my dearest belief, that it’s the imagination which could save the world, that if we imagined our neighbor’s griefs we would not do to him what we don’t want him to do to us. Frieda says that, having imagined what it’s like to be the abused Jew, Shakespeare confiscates half his fortune, hounds him ignominiously off the stage, and makes him convert.”

“I’m going to open a bottle of wine,” Farah says. “Ilka, go on.”

Ilka says, “Frieda argues that the basis for our innate difference is my inclination for seeing sameness where hers is for seeing distinctions. Where I search for harmony in equality, she sees how one thing—one people, history, ethos—is distinct from another. Frieda says that for me distinctions spell the disruption of harmony; that, for her, harmony is a lie where distinction is present.

“ ‘Harmony?’ I holler. ‘What, me? Aren’t I your favorite contrarian, your in-house skeptic who tests your every certainty by opposing my uncertainties? Do, please, notice,’ I tell her, ‘that I end with my universal question mark.’

“But then she asked if I and you—my ‘Lunch Ladies’—still vote on the left, and I said, ‘You bet,’ and we were back on the bus, you see. I e-mailed her: ‘I’m discouraged.’ She answered, ‘For the record (if there is a record) I feel terrible, not simply discouraged but terrible.’

“I wrote her, ‘I don’t know if it will ease your distress, but I reconfirm my love and friendship if you will accept them with the acceptance also of our irreconcilable differences, which are totally unchanged after half a century’s disputation.

“She answered, ‘Noted. Confirmed and renewed.’ ”

Ilka says, “And then I dreamed that there was something essential that has to be prevented.” ♦
story_a:
In the liminal space between consciousness and oblivion, Maria found herself in a vast expanse of nothingness, a shimmering, dreamlike landscape where the air itself seemed to pulse with an otherworldly glow. She could feel her heart beating against her ribcage, a rhythmic drum that synchronized with the distant hum of the void. She looked around, trying to orient herself, but there was no horizon, no sky, no ground—just an endless continuum of muted light and shadow.

Then, she saw him. Samuel, her dearest friend, stood at a distance, his figure clear and sharp against the nebulous backdrop. He was waving at her, a frantic motion that spoke of urgency and desperation. She started towards him, her steps slow at first, but then quicker, more determined. But with each stride, the space between them seemed to stretch, an elastic chasm that refused to close.

"Maria!" Samuel's voice cut through the silence, a plaintive cry that made her heart ache. "I need to tell you something. It's important."

She tried to shout back, but her voice was swallowed by the vastness, her words dissipating into the ether. Frustration welled up inside her, a familiar companion in their recent conversations, where dialogues often turned into debates, and debates into arguments. They had once shared a singular vision of the world, a tapestry woven from shared experiences and dreams. But lately, their threads had frayed, pulled apart by the weight of their diverging beliefs.

An abyss yawned suddenly between them, a dark, gaping maw that seemed to absorb all light and sound. Maria hesitated at its edge, the chasm too wide, too deep to traverse. She could see Samuel on the other side, his face lined with worry, his eyes pleading.

"Maria, please!" he called, his voice trembling. "You have to listen."

She knew that she had to reach him, that something critical hinged on this message. But how? The abyss was impassable, a physical manifestation of the emotional distance that had grown between them. She took a deep breath, closed her eyes, and took a leap of faith. But instead of falling, she found herself suspended, floating weightlessly across the divide. When she landed on the other side, Samuel was there, his face a mixture of relief and apprehension.

"Thank you," he said quietly, his voice raw with emotion. "I didn't know if you'd come."

"Of course, I would," she replied, her tone softer than she intended. "What is it, Samuel? What's so urgent?"

He reached into his pocket and pulled out a small, crumpled piece of paper. "It's about us," he said, handing it to her. "About everything we've been through. I need you to understand."

She unfolded the paper, her eyes scanning the hastily written words. It was a letter, a confession of sorts, filled with memories of their shared past, moments of joy and sorrow, and a heartfelt plea for reconciliation. As she read, tears filled her eyes, blurring the ink on the page.

"Samuel," she whispered, her voice choked with emotion. "Why didn't you just tell me this before?"

"I tried," he said, his voice breaking. "But every time I did, we ended up fighting. I didn't know how to bridge the gap between us."

She looked at him, her heart aching with a mixture of love and regret. "I miss you," she said simply. "I miss us."

"Me too," he replied, his eyes glistening. "But we can't keep pretending that our differences don't matter. We have to find a way to coexist, to respect each other's beliefs, even if we can't agree on everything."

Maria nodded, a heavy sigh escaping her lips. "I know," she said. "But it's so hard. Sometimes it feels like we're speaking different languages, like there's a wall between us that we can't break through."

He took her hand, his touch warm and reassuring. "Then let's start by listening," he said. "Really listening. Maybe if we understand where the other is coming from, we can find common ground."

She squeezed his hand, a small gesture that spoke volumes. "I'll try," she said. "I'll really try."

They stood there in silence, the abyss still present but somehow less daunting. It was as if the simple act of reaching out, of acknowledging their differences and their shared history, had shrunk the chasm, made it more manageable.

In that moment, the dream began to shift. The void around them shimmered and transformed, the edges of their reality blurring into a new landscape. They found themselves in a familiar place, the park where they had spent countless afternoons as children, their laughter echoing through the trees. The sky was a brilliant blue, the sun warm on their faces.

"Do you remember this?" Samuel asked, his voice filled with nostalgia.

"How could I forget?" Maria replied, a smile tugging at her lips. "We used to race to that old oak tree every day after school."

He grinned, a boyish light in his eyes. "You always won."

"Only because you let me," she said, nudging him playfully.

They walked together, the memories flooding back, each step a reminder of the bond they shared. The park was a symbol, a tangible representation of their friendship, a place where the walls between them had never existed.

As they reached the oak tree, they sat down beneath its sprawling branches, the shade cool and comforting. "This is what we need," Samuel said softly. "A place where we can be ourselves, where our differences don't divide us."

Maria nodded, the weight of their recent conflicts lifting slightly. "I think we can find that place," she said. "But it will take effort, from both of us."

"Agreed," he said, his voice firm. "We'll take it one day at a time, one conversation at a time."

They sat in companionable silence, the rustle of leaves and the distant chirping of birds providing a soothing soundtrack. In the quiet moments, they found a new understanding, a tentative but hopeful beginning.

As the dream began to fade, the park dissolving into a soft haze, Maria felt a sense of peace. She knew that their journey was far from over, that the challenges they faced were real and daunting. But she also knew that they had taken the first step, that they had chosen to bridge the abyss and dismantle the wall, one brick at a time.

When she awoke, the morning light filtering through her bedroom window, she felt a renewed sense of purpose. She picked up her phone, her fingers trembling slightly as she dialed Samuel's number. As it rang, she took a deep breath, ready to continue the conversation that had begun in their shared dream.

"Hello?" His voice, groggy with sleep, came through the line.

"Samuel, it's Maria," she said, her voice steady. "Can we talk?"

There was a pause, and then, "Of course," he replied, a note of hope in his voice. "I'd like that."

And so, they began anew, two friends bound by love, determined to bridge the divide, one conversation at a time.
story_b:
In the twilight of a dreamscape, Claire and David stood on opposite sides of a vast abyss. The chasm was a swirling void, a tempest of past arguments and forgotten grievances, echoing with the ghosts of their shared history. Above them, the sky was a canvas of surreal colors—violets mingling with oranges, as if dusk and dawn were perpetually entwined.

“Iforget,” Ilka says to the friends around the table. “Do we allow ourselves to tell our dreams?”

“You have a good one?” Bessie asks her.

“You know the kind of movie in which something has to be prevented? In this dream, there is some fatal thing I need urgently to say to my cousin Frieda, but she is on the far side of an abyss, and then she is on the other side of a wall.”

“What’s the urgent thing you need to say to her?”

“The dream doesn’t specify.”

The friends, who have been meeting for lunch for some thirty years, live in a fifteen-block area on the Upper West Side. They talk the politics you expect on the Upper West Side of New York, except when Ilka is talking to them about her cousin Frieda Fishgoppel, professor of philosophy, now emerita.

Ilka says, “The dream is something to do with our most recent reconciliation.”

“Why reconcile when you know that you will keep quarrelling?” Farah asks.

“Our project,” Ilka says, “is to be reconciled to quarrelling.”

“But why do you keep the argument going?” asks Ruth, the bona-fide retired activist. “You disagree with everything she stands for and disbelieve what she believes.”

“And believe,” Ilka says, “in her inalienable right to believe what I disagree with. It’s in the nature, on my part certainly, of a demonstration, proof that we live in a democracy where people—and people we love—may have different, have wrong, opinions.”

“And she is game to let you keep disagreeing?” asks Bridget.

“Nnnnno,” Ilka says rather slowly. “But I like, I love, the intelligible, passionate language in which she disagrees. Frieda is in love with her truths in a way I do not love mine. And you all know that she was my ticket to America—my old ur-story.”

“Tell it again,” the friends say, and settle themselves on their chairs.

“After the end of the war,” Ilka says, “Frieda searched for the western, Viennese branch of our family. The generation of the grandparents who weren’t dead of old age had been killed in the camps, but there were cousins who had emigrated to Uruguay, to Paraguay, to the Dominican Republic, to Argentina. An uncle went to Canada. Frieda sent the visa for me to come to New York. She settled me in her funny little apartment in Washington Heights—in the fifties, there were so many of us we called it Washingstein Heights. She handed me an Oxford English Dictionary and hurried back to New Haven for her exams. She would come in to see if I was O.K., bring me ‘David Copperfield’ or a Jane Austen. I had arrived speaking minimal English, but all the refugees were soon reading novels in English, though maybe not the Henry James that Frieda brought me.”

“What was her field?” Ruth asks.

“Frieda’s first Ph.D. was in literature, and her dissertation was about antisemitism in her favorite writings from—I don’t exactly remember—was it ‘Beowulf’ to Eliot?

“Frieda and I still e-mail. If we don’t hear from each other, we worry. ‘The earth is flat and has four sharp corners,’ she writes me. ‘It’s easy to drop off the edge.’ She has not replied to my last, and so I promptly assume that she has fallen! She is in emergency! Or, this time, did I go too far?”

Crossword Puzzles with a Side of Millennial Socialism


“But what about?’’ Bridget asks.

“I’m trying to remember—what were we saying on the bus in Jerusalem?” Ilka muses. “Frieda and I were travelling with a group of Americans—that was in the eighties. We were sitting, talking, and she remembers that I got up and walked away and that I got off the bus. I remember that we did not talk for the last leg of the trip. We didn’t get together back in New York until Lotte invited both of us to dinner. She left us in a room together with the door shut, and Frieda and I started to laugh. You and I, we said to each other, we don’t have to go on doing this. You know what I will say, and I know what you are going to answer. But to this day we are still arguing the same opposing politics without having made a dent in each other’s opinion.”

“Her wrong opinion, which leads her to vote on the wrong side,” Ruth says.

“Which she believes to be the right side as fully as she believes that yours and mine is wrong.”

“And you know the disastrous consequences of hers,” Ruth says.

“That’s why I walked off the bus, I suppose,” says Ilka.

“But you go on talking.”

“We go on talking.”

Bridget says, “You keep not telling us what you argue about.”

“Because I am more interested in the fact, the nature, of disagreement,” Ilka says. “Also, it keeps the conversation from going to Israel, though Frieda says, correctly I think, that ‘to not go there’ is to silence speech.”

Ruth asks, “So exactly what is the dispute?”

Ilka says, “One way of putting it is that I choose to think of myself as a humanist, a child of Adam, where Frieda thinks of herself as a child of God-chosen Abraham. The DNA, as she says, will be the same.

“I search for what Isaac, the progenitor of Israel, has in common with his brother Ishmael, progenitor of Canaan: They both laugh if you tickle them and bleed when you prick them, which drives poor Frieda frantic. She says Shakespeare probably never met a Jew in his life. She challenges—no, she demolishes—my dearest belief, that it’s the imagination which could save the world, that if we imagined our neighbor’s griefs we would not do to him what we don’t want him to do to us. Frieda says that, having imagined what it’s like to be the abused Jew, Shakespeare confiscates half his fortune, hounds him ignominiously off the stage, and makes him convert.”

“I’m going to open a bottle of wine,” Farah says. “Ilka, go on.”

Ilka says, “Frieda argues that the basis for our innate difference is my inclination for seeing sameness where hers is for seeing distinctions. Where I search for harmony in equality, she sees how one thing—one people, history, ethos—is distinct from another. Frieda says that for me distinctions spell the disruption of harmony; that, for her, harmony is a lie where distinction is present.

“ ‘Harmony?’ I holler. ‘What, me? Aren’t I your favorite contrarian, your in-house skeptic who tests your every certainty by opposing my uncertainties? Do, please, notice,’ I tell her, ‘that I end with my universal question mark.’

“But then she asked if I and you—my ‘Lunch Ladies’—still vote on the left, and I said, ‘You bet,’ and we were back on the bus, you see. I e-mailed her: ‘I’m discouraged.’ She answered, ‘For the record (if there is a record) I feel terrible, not simply discouraged but terrible.’

“I wrote her, ‘I don’t know if it will ease your distress, but I reconfirm my love and friendship if you will accept them with the acceptance also of our irreconcilable differences, which are totally unchanged after half a century’s disputation.

“She answered, ‘Noted. Confirmed and renewed.’ ”

Ilka says, “And then I dreamed that there was something essential that has to be prevented.” ♦
story_a:
In the liminal space between consciousness and oblivion, Maria found herself in a vast expanse of nothingness, a shimmering, dreamlike landscape where the air itself seemed to pulse with an otherworldly glow. She could feel her heart beating against her ribcage, a rhythmic drum that synchronized with the distant hum of the void. She looked around, trying to orient herself, but there was no horizon, no sky, no ground—just an endless continuum of muted light and shadow.

Then, she saw him. Samuel, her dearest friend, stood at a distance, his figure clear and sharp against the nebulous backdrop. He was waving at her, a frantic motion that spoke of urgency and desperation. She started towards him, her steps slow at first, but then quicker, more determined. But with each stride, the space between them seemed to stretch, an elastic chasm that refused to close.

"Maria!" Samuel's voice cut through the silence, a plaintive cry that made her heart ache. "I need to tell you something. It's important."

She tried to shout back, but her voice was swallowed by the vastness, her words dissipating into the ether. Frustration welled up inside her, a familiar companion in their recent conversations, where dialogues often turned into debates, and debates into arguments. They had once shared a singular vision of the world, a tapestry woven from shared experiences and dreams. But lately, their threads had frayed, pulled apart by the weight of their diverging beliefs.

An abyss yawned suddenly between them, a dark, gaping maw that seemed to absorb all light and sound. Maria hesitated at its edge, the chasm too wide, too deep to traverse. She could see Samuel on the other side, his face lined with worry, his eyes pleading.

"Maria, please!" he called, his voice trembling. "You have to listen."

She knew that she had to reach him, that something critical hinged on this message. But how? The abyss was impassable, a physical manifestation of the emotional distance that had grown between them. She took a deep breath, closed her eyes, and took a leap of faith. But instead of falling, she found herself suspended, floating weightlessly across the divide. When she landed on the other side, Samuel was there, his face a mixture of relief and apprehension.

"Thank you," he said quietly, his voice raw with emotion. "I didn't know if you'd come."

"Of course, I would," she replied, her tone softer than she intended. "What is it, Samuel? What's so urgent?"

He reached into his pocket and pulled out a small, crumpled piece of paper. "It's about us," he said, handing it to her. "About everything we've been through. I need you to understand."

She unfolded the paper, her eyes scanning the hastily written words. It was a letter, a confession of sorts, filled with memories of their shared past, moments of joy and sorrow, and a heartfelt plea for reconciliation. As she read, tears filled her eyes, blurring the ink on the page.

"Samuel," she whispered, her voice choked with emotion. "Why didn't you just tell me this before?"

"I tried," he said, his voice breaking. "But every time I did, we ended up fighting. I didn't know how to bridge the gap between us."

She looked at him, her heart aching with a mixture of love and regret. "I miss you," she said simply. "I miss us."

"Me too," he replied, his eyes glistening. "But we can't keep pretending that our differences don't matter. We have to find a way to coexist, to respect each other's beliefs, even if we can't agree on everything."

Maria nodded, a heavy sigh escaping her lips. "I know," she said. "But it's so hard. Sometimes it feels like we're speaking different languages, like there's a wall between us that we can't break through."

He took her hand, his touch warm and reassuring. "Then let's start by listening," he said. "Really listening. Maybe if we understand where the other is coming from, we can find common ground."

She squeezed his hand, a small gesture that spoke volumes. "I'll try," she said. "I'll really try."

They stood there in silence, the abyss still present but somehow less daunting. It was as if the simple act of reaching out, of acknowledging their differences and their shared history, had shrunk the chasm, made it more manageable.

In that moment, the dream began to shift. The void around them shimmered and transformed, the edges of their reality blurring into a new landscape. They found themselves in a familiar place, the park where they had spent countless afternoons as children, their laughter echoing through the trees. The sky was a brilliant blue, the sun warm on their faces.

"Do you remember this?" Samuel asked, his voice filled with nostalgia.

"How could I forget?" Maria replied, a smile tugging at her lips. "We used to race to that old oak tree every day after school."

He grinned, a boyish light in his eyes. "You always won."

"Only because you let me," she said, nudging him playfully.

They walked together, the memories flooding back, each step a reminder of the bond they shared. The park was a symbol, a tangible representation of their friendship, a place where the walls between them had never existed.

As they reached the oak tree, they sat down beneath its sprawling branches, the shade cool and comforting. "This is what we need," Samuel said softly. "A place where we can be ourselves, where our differences don't divide us."

Maria nodded, the weight of their recent conflicts lifting slightly. "I think we can find that place," she said. "But it will take effort, from both of us."

"Agreed," he said, his voice firm. "We'll take it one day at a time, one conversation at a time."

They sat in companionable silence, the rustle of leaves and the distant chirping of birds providing a soothing soundtrack. In the quiet moments, they found a new understanding, a tentative but hopeful beginning.

As the dream began to fade, the park dissolving into a soft haze, Maria felt a sense of peace. She knew that their journey was far from over, that the challenges they faced were real and daunting. But she also knew that they had taken the first step, that they had chosen to bridge the abyss and dismantle the wall, one brick at a time.

When she awoke, the morning light filtering through her bedroom window, she felt a renewed sense of purpose. She picked up her phone, her fingers trembling slightly as she dialed Samuel's number. As it rang, she took a deep breath, ready to continue the conversation that had begun in their shared dream.

"Hello?" His voice, groggy with sleep, came through the line.

"Samuel, it's Maria," she said, her voice steady. "Can we talk?"

There was a pause, and then, "Of course," he replied, a note of hope in his voice. "I'd like that."

And so, they began anew, two friends bound by love, determined to bridge the divide, one conversation at a time.
story_b:
In the dream, Daniel stood at the precipice of an abyss that seemed to stretch beyond the horizons of his imagination. The air was thick with anticipation, as if even the sky held its breath. He clutched the message—a slip of paper upon which the words danced like flames, their urgency searing his palms. Across the gaping void, he saw Miriam, her figure a silhouette against the dim glow of the horizon, unreachable yet achingly near.

The abyss was not just a physical chasm; it was the embodiment of every silence that had grown between them, every conversation steered away from the dangerous terrain of their differences. Politics, faith, the very nature of truth—these were fissures that had, over time, widened into this unbridgeable gulf. Yet, the message in his hand demanded delivery, a fragile bird of hope and desperation.

Daniel took a deep breath, the air laced with the scent of memories. In the dream's fluidity, he remembered the laughter shared under summer skies, debates that once sparked with the joy of discovery rather than the bitterness of dissent. He longed to call out to her, to span the distance with words, but his voice was tethered by the weight of things unsaid.

The dream shifted, as dreams do, and suddenly he was at the edge of the abyss with a bridge forming beneath his feet—a bridge not of stone or wood, but of memories. Each step was a vignette: the time they danced in the rain, the night they sat on the roof counting stars, the arguments that ended in promises of forever friendship. The bridge wavered, as if uncertain of its own solidity, reflecting the fragile nature of their bond.

As Daniel moved forward, the abyss below whispered echoes of past arguments, the words looping endlessly like a forgotten song. He paused, feeling the bridge shudder under the weight of an unresolved past. He looked across at Miriam, who stood unmoving, her expression a tapestry of hope and fear.

The dreamscape morphed again, and the bridge disappeared, replaced by a wall—an immense, towering barrier that pulsated with a life of its own. It was constructed of shifting words and images, a collage of their conflicting beliefs. Political slogans and philosophical maxims wove in and out of each other, creating a living mural that writhed with tension.

Daniel approached the wall, feeling its energy thrumming through his fingertips. Each section was a chapter of their shared history, each brick a decision point where paths had diverged. He could see Miriam on the other side, her fingers tracing the contours of their past, her eyes meeting his through the translucent stone.

"This wall," he thought, "is not just stone and mortar, but the embodiment of every unspoken word and unresolved conflict between us." He pressed his hand against it, willing it to dissolve, to crumble under the weight of their shared humanity.

In the dream's strange logic, he saw his words transform into birds—flocks of iridescent creatures that flew towards Miriam, only to be caught by the gusting winds, swirling back into the abyss. Each bird carried a message: an apology, a declaration, an acknowledgment of her truth. But the winds of their differences were relentless, scattering his words before they could reach her.

Miriam watched the birds with a wistful smile, her eyes reflecting the kaleidoscope of their shared history. She too reached for the wall, her fingers brushing against the shifting images. In the silence, she heard Daniel's voice, not as it was now, but as it had been—young, untainted by the scars of time.

The dream shifted once more, and Daniel found himself in a garden, lush and overgrown, where the wall had become a hedge of thorns. The air was heavy with the scent of roses and rain, an intoxicating blend of beauty and danger. He knew that somewhere within this maze lay the message's true destination—a place where words could be spoken freely, where understanding might blossom.

He pushed through the thorns, feeling their bite against his skin. Each scratch was a reminder of the pain their differences had wrought, but he pressed on, driven by the urgency of the message. He could hear Miriam on the other side, her voice a song of longing and regret.

As he emerged into a clearing, he saw her waiting, her face lit by the soft glow of dreamlight. The hedge still separated them, but here, in this place of quiet reflection, the air was different—calmer, imbued with the possibility of reconciliation.

"Miriam," he called out, his voice finally finding its strength. "I have something to say."

She looked at him, her eyes weary yet hopeful. "I’m listening," she replied, the words a bridge in themselves.

Daniel held the message aloft, letting it unfurl in the dream's gentle breeze. "I don't know if we can ever truly reconcile our beliefs," he began, his voice steady. "But I do know that our friendship means more to me than being right. Can we find a way to honor that?"

Miriam smiled, a soft, tentative smile that spoke of old wounds and new beginnings. "I think we can try," she said, her voice a balm to the fractures between them.

In that moment, the hedge of thorns began to wither, its blooms falling away to reveal a path—a path not of perfect unity, but of mutual respect, where their differences could coexist alongside their love.

The dream began to fade, the surreal landscape dissolving into the soft edges of waking. As Daniel drifted towards consciousness, he felt the message slip from his grasp, its urgency replaced by a quiet understanding that lingered in his heart.

When he awoke, it was with the realization that dreams, like friendships, are not always about resolution. Sometimes they are about the journey, the willingness to reach across the void, to stand before the wall and see it not as a barrier, but as a shared history that can be rewritten.

He picked up the phone, dialing her number with a newfound resolve. The message had been delivered, not in words, but in the willingness to try again, to bridge the abyss with the strength of their bond. As the line connected, he knew that they would find a way, together, to navigate the labyrinth of their differences, to cherish the path they had chosen to walk side by side.

“I wrote her, ‘I don’t know if it will ease your distress, but I reconfirm my love and friendship if you will accept them with the acceptance also of our irreconcilable differences, which are totally unchanged after half a century’s disputation.

“She answered, ‘Noted. Confirmed and renewed.’ ”

Ilka says, “And then I dreamed that there was something essential that has to be prevented.” ♦
story_a:
In the liminal space between consciousness and oblivion, Maria found herself in a vast expanse of nothingness, a shimmering, dreamlike landscape where the air itself seemed to pulse with an otherworldly glow. She could feel her heart beating against her ribcage, a rhythmic drum that synchronized with the distant hum of the void. She looked around, trying to orient herself, but there was no horizon, no sky, no ground—just an endless continuum of muted light and shadow.

Then, she saw him. Samuel, her dearest friend, stood at a distance, his figure clear and sharp against the nebulous backdrop. He was waving at her, a frantic motion that spoke of urgency and desperation. She started towards him, her steps slow at first, but then quicker, more determined. But with each stride, the space between them seemed to stretch, an elastic chasm that refused to close.

"Maria!" Samuel's voice cut through the silence, a plaintive cry that made her heart ache. "I need to tell you something. It's important."

She tried to shout back, but her voice was swallowed by the vastness, her words dissipating into the ether. Frustration welled up inside her, a familiar companion in their recent conversations, where dialogues often turned into debates, and debates into arguments. They had once shared a singular vision of the world, a tapestry woven from shared experiences and dreams. But lately, their threads had frayed, pulled apart by the weight of their diverging beliefs.

An abyss yawned suddenly between them, a dark, gaping maw that seemed to absorb all light and sound. Maria hesitated at its edge, the chasm too wide, too deep to traverse. She could see Samuel on the other side, his face lined with worry, his eyes pleading.

"Maria, please!" he called, his voice trembling. "You have to listen."

She knew that she had to reach him, that something critical hinged on this message. But how? The abyss was impassable, a physical manifestation of the emotional distance that had grown between them. She took a deep breath, closed her eyes, and took a leap of faith. But instead of falling, she found herself suspended, floating weightlessly across the divide. When she landed on the other side, Samuel was there, his face a mixture of relief and apprehension.

"Thank you," he said quietly, his voice raw with emotion. "I didn't know if you'd come."

"Of course, I would," she replied, her tone softer than she intended. "What is it, Samuel? What's so urgent?"

He reached into his pocket and pulled out a small, crumpled piece of paper. "It's about us," he said, handing it to her. "About everything we've been through. I need you to understand."

She unfolded the paper, her eyes scanning the hastily written words. It was a letter, a confession of sorts, filled with memories of their shared past, moments of joy and sorrow, and a heartfelt plea for reconciliation. As she read, tears filled her eyes, blurring the ink on the page.

"Samuel," she whispered, her voice choked with emotion. "Why didn't you just tell me this before?"

"I tried," he said, his voice breaking. "But every time I did, we ended up fighting. I didn't know how to bridge the gap between us."

She looked at him, her heart aching with a mixture of love and regret. "I miss you," she said simply. "I miss us."

"Me too," he replied, his eyes glistening. "But we can't keep pretending that our differences don't matter. We have to find a way to coexist, to respect each other's beliefs, even if we can't agree on everything."

Maria nodded, a heavy sigh escaping her lips. "I know," she said. "But it's so hard. Sometimes it feels like we're speaking different languages, like there's a wall between us that we can't break through."

He took her hand, his touch warm and reassuring. "Then let's start by listening," he said. "Really listening. Maybe if we understand where the other is coming from, we can find common ground."

She squeezed his hand, a small gesture that spoke volumes. "I'll try," she said. "I'll really try."

They stood there in silence, the abyss still present but somehow less daunting. It was as if the simple act of reaching out, of acknowledging their differences and their shared history, had shrunk the chasm, made it more manageable.

In that moment, the dream began to shift. The void around them shimmered and transformed, the edges of their reality blurring into a new landscape. They found themselves in a familiar place, the park where they had spent countless afternoons as children, their laughter echoing through the trees. The sky was a brilliant blue, the sun warm on their faces.

"Do you remember this?" Samuel asked, his voice filled with nostalgia.

"How could I forget?" Maria replied, a smile tugging at her lips. "We used to race to that old oak tree every day after school."

He grinned, a boyish light in his eyes. "You always won."

"Only because you let me," she said, nudging him playfully.

They walked together, the memories flooding back, each step a reminder of the bond they shared. The park was a symbol, a tangible representation of their friendship, a place where the walls between them had never existed.

As they reached the oak tree, they sat down beneath its sprawling branches, the shade cool and comforting. "This is what we need," Samuel said softly. "A place where we can be ourselves, where our differences don't divide us."

Maria nodded, the weight of their recent conflicts lifting slightly. "I think we can find that place," she said. "But it will take effort, from both of us."

"Agreed," he said, his voice firm. "We'll take it one day at a time, one conversation at a time."

They sat in companionable silence, the rustle of leaves and the distant chirping of birds providing a soothing soundtrack. In the quiet moments, they found a new understanding, a tentative but hopeful beginning.

As the dream began to fade, the park dissolving into a soft haze, Maria felt a sense of peace. She knew that their journey was far from over, that the challenges they faced were real and daunting. But she also knew that they had taken the first step, that they had chosen to bridge the abyss and dismantle the wall, one brick at a time.

When she awoke, the morning light filtering through her bedroom window, she felt a renewed sense of purpose. She picked up her phone, her fingers trembling slightly as she dialed Samuel's number. As it rang, she took a deep breath, ready to continue the conversation that had begun in their shared dream.

"Hello?" His voice, groggy with sleep, came through the line.

"Samuel, it's Maria," she said, her voice steady. "Can we talk?"

There was a pause, and then, "Of course," he replied, a note of hope in his voice. "I'd like that."

And so, they began anew, two friends bound by love, determined to bridge the divide, one conversation at a time.
story_b:
In the surreal dreamscape, the world stretched out in a hazy gradient of twilight hues. A vast abyss yawned between two figures standing on opposite edges, casting shadows that reached out like hands, eager to bridge the divide. The air was cool and damp, a whispering mist swirling around them, echoing with unspoken words and promises long past. To the left, a great wall rose with stones as ancient as their shared history, each brick etched with memories and arguments, standing testament to the years of their friendship.

On one side of the chasm stood Lena, her silhouette sharp against the murky backdrop, her heart heavy with urgency. She clutched a letter, its edges curling under the weight of her grasp. Across from her, on the other side, was Mark, his stance wary yet unyielding, eyes searching hers for a sign of the message she bore.

“Lena, what is this place?” Mark’s voice carried over the abyss, laced with a mix of fear and curiosity.

“A dream, perhaps,” Lena replied, her voice trembling slightly, “or a nightmare. I need you to understand why this matters.”

Mark laughed, a sound that was both familiar and foreign. “You always said our beliefs would tear us apart. Maybe this is the universe’s way of proving you right.”

“Maybe we should just build a bridge out of our stubbornness,” Lena quipped, trying to inject humor into the heavy air, but the joke fell flat, swallowed by the chasm between them.

As they stood there, the dreamscape shifted, memories swirling in the mist like specters. Lena recalled a sunlit afternoon, years ago, when they had sat on a park bench, arguing over a book. She had been passionate, animated, insisting on her interpretation, while Mark had listened, nodding along, until he could no longer suppress his differing view. It had been a pivotal moment, a first glimpse into the chasm that would later grow between them.

“Remember that day in the park?” Lena called out, her voice softer now, tinged with nostalgia. “We were so young, so sure of ourselves. It was the first time I realized we saw the world through different lenses.”

Mark nodded slowly, his gaze distant as he too wandered back to that afternoon. “I thought it was thrilling,” he admitted, “debating with someone who challenged me. But I never imagined it would lead us here.”

“We’ve always been on opposite sides, haven’t we?” Lena mused, watching as the abyss seemed to narrow for a fleeting moment, a bridge of understanding almost forming before it vanished again.

Mark sighed, the sound resonating with the distant rumble of shifting earth. “Sometimes I wonder why I can’t let this go. Why can’t I accept that we’re different?”

“Because it matters, Mark,” Lena said, her voice firm. “Because these differences are not just in our heads; they’re part of who we are.”

The wall behind Lena shimmered, and figures began to emerge from its surface—secondary characters from their past, living echoes of their shared journey. There was Hannah, their college friend, who had always been the peacekeeper, and Rob, the one who had introduced them all those years ago, his laughter still a faint memory in their minds.

“Look,” Lena pointed, her eyes wide with surprise. “They’re here. Do you remember what Hannah used to say?”

Mark smiled, despite himself. “‘Agree to disagree, but never stop listening.’ She always believed we’d find common ground.”

“Maybe she was right,” Lena said wistfully. “Or maybe we’ve just been too proud to see it.”

The mist swirled thicker, and the figures faded back into the stone, leaving Lena and Mark alone once more, facing the expanse that separated them. The tension was palpable, each of them holding their beliefs close like shields, yet the letter in Lena’s hand felt heavier than any conviction.

“Lena, what’s in the letter?” Mark asked, his curiosity piqued.

“It’s... a confession,” Lena admitted, her voice barely a whisper. “Something I’ve been meaning to tell you for a long time.”

“Why now?” Mark pressed, his voice urgent.

“Because this dream, this place, it’s showing me how far apart we’ve drifted. And I’m scared, Mark. I’m scared of losing you.”

The abyss seemed to pulse with her words, and for a moment, it felt as though the earth beneath them trembled in response. Mark took a step closer to the edge, his heart pounding with an emotion he couldn’t quite name.

“Lena, I’ve been scared too. Scared that one day, we’d wake up and find ourselves strangers.”

Lena nodded, tears glistening in her eyes. “We’ve let our beliefs build this wall, widen this abyss. But maybe, just maybe, we can find a way to understand each other.”

Mark’s eyes softened, his defenses crumbling ever so slightly. “I’ve missed this, Lena—this honesty between us. I want to hear your confession.”

Lena hesitated, then took a deep breath, the mist swirling around her like a protective cloak. “I’ve always admired you, Mark. Even when we fought, even when I thought I couldn’t understand you. You’ve made me question, challenge, and grow. And... I’m sorry for the times I let my pride get in the way.”

The abyss seemed to draw in a breath, the mist curling tighter around them, as if the dream itself was holding its breath for his response.

Mark smiled, a real smile this time, and nodded slowly. “Thank you, Lena. For saying that. For being brave enough to bridge this gap, even if just for a moment.”

The dreamscape shimmered, the abyss narrowing ever so slightly, though the wall remained steadfast. It was clear that the divide would not close overnight, that their differences were too deeply ingrained. Yet, in that dream, there was a sense of peace, a mutual understanding that hadn’t been there before.

“I think,” Lena said, her voice gentle, “that this message, this dream, was worth the risk.”

Mark nodded, stepping back from the edge, his heart lighter. “And maybe, when we wake, we can work on building that bridge. Out of more than just stubbornness.”

As the dream began to dissolve, the mist reclaiming its hold over the landscape, Lena and Mark stood there, separated by the abyss but connected by something deeper—a shared history, a love that transcended their differences, and the hope of a future where understanding could be their guide.

In the end, as the cool, damp air faded and the dream released them back to reality, Lena and Mark carried with them the knowledge that while the abyss remained, they had found a way to see each other across it, and perhaps, in time, they could learn to meet in the middle.

prompt: Two overworked women with mismatched schedules finally have a rare morning off together in their cozy, cluttered apartment—what small, quiet moments make it feel like home?
ground_truth:
The flat is quiet when Obi-Wan manages to wrangle the door open through a mess of foliage and delicate string lights that throng their hallway. No need to worry about alarms or a security system when they had the normal mess and clutter of everyday life. She steps over Cody’s work boots, placed into the same spot every day, and loosely toes her own shoes off next to them. The sole gapes wide as she does so, revealing the softer innards of fabric straining away from rubber, and she ignores it as best as she can.
Tape is a godsend and where tape wouldn’t fix it, there is a small tube of superglue in one of the drawers she can ask Cody to try. The pads of Obi-Wan’s fingers are still discoloured from her last attempt at trying to fix a pair of her shoes so she’ll pass the problem to more capable hands. Her jacket is summarily discarded onto the back of the sofa and she lingers long enough to retrieve her lanyard and keys from the pocket, returning them to their forced exclusion into the small bowl on the counter for the next two days. The time off from work stretches luxuriously empty, free from any mandatory training or social obligations, and Obi-Wan skirts around the potential issue of their unique living arrangement as she flicks on the kettle, pulling one mug out of the cupboard, pausing and returning for another. Cody has the next couple of days off as well, a rarity with their opposite working schedules. Obi-Wan makes Cody’s cup of coffee how she likes it, strong and sweet and a splash of milk first despite Obi-Wan’s moral objections to the concept, and rifles through her small collection of tea. There is no caffeine in her immediate future if she wants to sleep for any part of the morning; another hidden delight of adulthood that’s tripped her over and bruised up her face. She chews on the tip of her tongue as she draws a bag free, dropping it into her cup and chasing it with the boiling water.
A door creaks further in the apartment and Obi-Wan rocks back onto her heels, a dozy prickle of contentment resting on the nape of her neck. Cody’s steps are steady, sleep-slow and her slippers smack against the floor as she makes her way into the sitting room. Much of her isn’t visible, a walking plaid blanket that hides her face and her curls, but the tattoo over her calf is clearly visible with one of her pyjama trouser legs drawn up over her knee while the other falls to the floor.
“Morning,” Obi-Wan says, breaking into a yawn that she doesn’t bother to hide behind her hand. Her manners are ingrained into her bones but even that runs thin and fallow after so long spent at work.
“G’morning,” Cody responds, her words muffled through fabric and sleep. Obi-Wan can picture her expression, her eyes still mostly closed and her gaze filtered through her impossibly long lashes and her grin easily worn in.
Obi-Wan follows her, both mugs in hand, and places them onto the clear spaces on their cluttered coffee table. She has options for seating, the low slouch of a battered armchair Obi-Wan carried to her student dorm, then flat, then four different flatshares before this one or the other end of the sofa that Cody has already claimed, piled high with blankets and a handful of cushions that Cody would claim as family heirlooms at the first hint of decluttering. She sits on Cody’s legs stretched out over the seat before she wriggles backwards into the hollow created. Cody grunts, shifting her legs straighter before she reaches down to tug a section of the blanket free, pulling it over Obi-Wan.
“You’re in early,” Cody mumbles. She’s partially spilled out of the blanket now wrapped around her waist. She stretches and her shirt rises with the motion, everything about her solid and real and beautiful.
Obi-Wan hums in agreement, leaning sideways against Cody who absorbs the motion with a soft sound. She wraps an arm around Obi-Wan’s shoulders, playing with the loose edge of her sleeve. “Move your head up a bit? You’re lying right on my tit.” Obi-Wan does so, her face flushed but it’s fine. It happens. Cody continues, her voice a little more structured as she wakes, “Figured you’d like the bed to sleep after your night shift so I came out here for the morning. It’ll be nice having us both around the house, little human company to prove I’m not just another cog in the machine.”
If Cody is a cog, then she would be the best cog imaginable, something brimming with lots of interlocking teeth, a fundamental piece of the machinery. Obi-Wan tells her this because why wouldn’t she? It makes perfect sense.
Cody tips her head back as she laughs, the sound vibrating through Obi-Wan like it would rattle all the broken pieces in her chest back together. She curls closer, crossing her legs one over the other and then swapping them back, and Cody rights herself carefully, smearing the heel of her palm across her eyes. She curls her hand around Obi-Wan’s head, drawing her face upwards. The air hangs still and heavy, steam curling from their mugs nearly forgotten on the table, and Cody leans down, kissing Obi-Wan. She tastes like coffee and a stale tang of sleep and like home. Obi-Wan grins against her mouth, pressing herself closer, the mugs and sleep entirely forgotten.
story_a:
Ahsoka Tano blinked awake to the gentle hum of Coruscant's never-sleeping cityscape, the early morning light filtering through the blinds of their modest apartment. For once, there was no alarm blaring, no urgent holocall summoning her to some far-off battlefield. Just the soft, serene quiet that only came with rare mornings like these.

She turned her head, a smile tugging at her lips as she took in the sight beside her. Padmé Amidala was still fast asleep, her chest rising and falling with the steady rhythm of deep slumber. In the dim light, Ahsoka could make out the soft curve of Padmé's cheek, the way her hair splayed out across the pillow in a messy halo. It was a sight she cherished, one she didn't see nearly often enough.

Careful not to disturb her, Ahsoka slipped out of bed, padding softly to the kitchen. Their apartment wasn't large, but it was cozy, filled with mementos from their adventures and trinkets that spoke of shared moments. On the fridge, a collection of holophotos captured snapshots of their lives: laughing faces at a Senate gala, candid shots from a picnic in the underlevels, a blurry image of Ahsoka mid-jump during a sparring match, taken by Padmé with a mischievous grin.

As she set about making caf, Ahsoka couldn't help but smile at the clutter that spoke of their busy lives. A half-finished datapad report from Padmé's latest Senate mission sat next to Ahsoka's scattered training holos, a testament to their mismatched schedules and endless responsibilities. Yet, in the midst of the chaos, there was a sense of home.

The smell of brewing caf eventually roused Padmé, who shuffled into the kitchen, still wrapped in the warmth of sleep. Ahsoka turned, a cup of steaming caf in each hand, and met her partner's sleepy gaze with a soft smile.

"Good morning," she said, handing Padmé a cup.

Padmé accepted it with a grateful hum, leaning into Ahsoka's side. "Morning," she murmured, taking a tentative sip. "Is it really morning? Or are we still dreaming?"

Ahsoka chuckled, wrapping an arm around her waist. "I think it's real. But if it is a dream, I don't want to wake up."

They stood there for a few moments, simply enjoying the quiet togetherness. It was these small, quiet moments that made the apartment feel like home, Ahsoka thought. The way Padmé's head fit perfectly against her shoulder, the warmth of her body against her side, the shared silence that spoke volumes.

"Let's make breakfast," Padmé suggested, pulling away just enough to set her cup down and start rummaging through the cabinets. "We never get to cook together anymore."

Ahsoka nodded, eager to prolong this rare morning. They moved around the kitchen with practiced ease, a dance of familiar steps and shared tasks. Ahsoka chopped vegetables while Padmé whisked eggs, and together they created a simple, hearty meal.

As they sat down to eat, Ahsoka glanced out the window, watching the sunlight dance across the buildings of Coruscant. It was a city of endless activity, but in their little apartment, time seemed to slow, allowing them to savor each moment.

Padmé reached across the table, her fingers brushing against Ahsoka's. "Thank you for this," she said softly, her eyes shining with affection. "For being here. For making this feel like home."

Ahsoka squeezed her hand, her heart swelling with love. "Always," she replied, her voice full of promise. "I'll always be here for you, Padmé."

They finished breakfast, the conversation flowing easily, filled with laughter and shared stories. When the last of the dishes were cleared away, they found themselves back in the living room, the clutter of their lives a comforting backdrop.

Padmé settled onto the couch, pulling Ahsoka down with her. They curled up together, the warmth of their bodies a soothing balm. Ahsoka rested her head on Padmé's lap, feeling her fingers gently comb through her montrals.

"It's funny," Padmé mused, her voice a soft murmur. "We've been through so much, seen so many places. But it's these quiet mornings that I treasure the most."

Ahsoka closed her eyes, letting the feeling of Padmé's touch and the sound of her voice wash over her. "Me too," she agreed. "It's the little things that make it all worth it."

They stayed like that for a while, wrapped in the comfort of each other's presence. There was no rush, no pressing demands. Just the simple joy of being together, of sharing a morning that felt like a precious gift.

In the end, it was these small, quiet moments that made their apartment feel like home. The way they fit together, the shared laughter and tender touches, the knowledge that no matter how chaotic their lives became, they had this—each other.

And as the morning light continued to fill their cozy, cluttered apartment, Ahsoka knew that this was all she needed. This love, this home, this beautiful, imperfect life they had built together.
story_b:
The morning light spills softly through the sheer curtains, casting gentle, shifting shadows on the cluttered shelves that line the living room. A soft breeze tugs at the edges of a quilt draped over the back of their well-worn couch, a testament to countless cozy evenings. Aayla Secura stretches, her muscles protesting from the residual tension of the week, and pads into the kitchen, her bare feet whispering against the cool tiles.

The kitchen is a snug space, filled with the paraphernalia of their lives together—quirky mugs perched precariously on shelves, a collection of spices that spills over the counter, and a haphazard stack of cookbooks that neither of them have ever really used. Aayla smiles to herself as she reaches for a mug, its handle shaped like a lightsaber, a gift from Barriss that she treasures for its sheer ridiculousness.

The kettle hisses on the stove, a familiar lullaby in the quiet morning. Aayla pours steaming water over the coffee grounds, the aroma rising to fill the kitchen, curling around her like a warm embrace. She glances over her shoulder as she hears a soft rustling from the bedroom.

Barriss Offee appears, her hair tousled and her steps slow, still caught in the hazy transition between sleep and wakefulness. She offers Aayla a sleepy smile, one that crinkles the corners of her eyes and makes Aayla's heart skip with a warmth that has nothing to do with the coffee. "Morning," Barriss murmurs, her voice soft and husky.

"Morning, love," Aayla replies, handing her a mug that reads 'Jedi Master of Coffee,' another of their whimsical treasures. Barriss takes it with a quiet chuckle, her fingers brushing against Aayla's, a small, intimate connection that speaks volumes.

They settle into their usual spots at the tiny kitchen table, its surface marked with years of use and memories. The soft glow of the morning light bathes them in a gentle, golden hue. Aayla watches Barriss as she absently straightens a stack of bills and letters, a habit that Aayla finds endlessly endearing. It's these little quirks, the familiar rhythm of their lives, that make this space truly theirs.

"We should probably do something about that," Barriss muses, gesturing to the stack with a rueful smile.

Aayla grins, taking a sip of her coffee. "Or we could just pretend it doesn't exist for another day," she suggests, the playful banter a comforting echo of countless mornings spent together.

Barriss laughs, a sound that fills the room with warmth. "You're incorrigible," she teases, but there's affection in her gaze as she reaches across the table to squeeze Aayla's hand.

Their fingers entwine, a silent promise of togetherness, and they sit in companionable silence, the world outside forgotten for a precious moment. The apartment is cluttered, a collection of their lives and the stories they’ve woven together. A well-loved plant sits on the windowsill, its leaves stretching toward the sun, just as they stretch toward each other, seeking and finding solace in shared moments.

"Do you remember when we first moved in here?" Barriss asks, her voice tinged with nostalgia.

Aayla nods, a smile playing on her lips. "Of course. We barely had any furniture, and we ate takeout on the floor for weeks."

"And you tried to convince me that a stack of books was a perfectly acceptable substitute for a nightstand," Barriss adds, a teasing lilt to her voice.

Aayla laughs, the sound bright and joyful. "Hey, it worked, didn’t it?" she defends, a playful glint in her eyes.

These are the moments that define them, the quiet rituals and shared laughter that create a sense of home and belonging. The cluttered shelves and mismatched mugs, the soft hum of the refrigerator, and the gentle glow of the morning light—all of it weaves a tapestry of their life together, each thread a memory, a connection, a testament to their shared journey.

As the morning unfurls, they linger in their cocoon of warmth and contentment, savoring the rare luxury of time spent together. Aayla leans back in her chair, her gaze resting on Barriss as she sketches idle patterns on the tabletop with her finger, lost in thought.

"What are you thinking about?" Aayla asks softly, her curiosity tinged with the simple desire to share in Barriss's world.

Barriss looks up, a smile curving her lips. "Just how lucky I am," she replies, her voice tender. "To have this, to have you."

Aayla’s heart swells with love, a feeling as vast and endless as the galaxy itself. She stands, moving around the table to join Barriss, wrapping her arms around her from behind. Barriss leans back against her, their silhouettes blending together, two parts of a whole.

The morning stretches before them, a canvas waiting to be filled with the quiet beauty of their everyday moments. For now, they are content to simply be, wrapped in the warmth of their shared space, the cozy clutter of their apartment a testament to the life they've built together. In this small, intimate cocoon, they find their home, a place where they belong, and the promise of countless mornings yet to come.
